reviewText: I hadn't read the book before watching this movie.As an author, I wanted to see how this subject was handled. I was interested in the pacing, the plot twists, the setting, and so on.As a fan of Daniel Radcliffe, I wanted to see how he handled this kind of role.In general, the pacing was slow, exactly as you'd expect from a classic gothic tale. The setting was a visual delight, and I recommend watching the movie with the commentary turned on (after seeing it, start to finish, without the commentary) to get the most from the way the movie was designed and produced.Radcliffe's performance was remarkable.  Large portions of the movie focus on him, alone, in a mundane (but creepy) setting.  He has no dialogue in many (perhaps most) scenes.  Despite that, he's able to convey the emotions of the character, and maintain interest.  Frankly, his performance is so compelling, it's almost hypnotic.Unfortunately, the movie isn't completely worthy of Radcliffe's efforts.One major problem was: the movie didn't convey a solid enough "character in his normal world" foundation at the start of the film.  We're too quickly thrown into his grief. Almost from the start, Radcliffe's character is a haunted man. (No pun intended. ) We see him living his life in the shallow, by-the-numbers manner that many grieving people adopt while they recover from a stunning loss.This film also falters due to some frankly cheesy visual elements.  I won't spoil the movie with details, because I think this IS a movie well worth watching, and owning for the special features included in the DVD.  However, the very last scene was such a cliche, it spoiled much of what had come before.  I couldn't help laughing when I saw it.I feel that the director tried to be all things to all moviegoers.  If he'd remained more faithful to the book, or to a classic "hero's journey" plot, or committed to making this a date-night horror flick, the movie would have been more successful.  Instead, it's part art film, part horror, and it's not full satisfying on either count.I'm reminded of the movie, "The Haunting," based on Shirley Jackson's novel.  The 1963 version was a classic -- now a little dated -- and inspired Disney's "Haunted Mansion" attraction. However, the 1999 remake tried to be an updated, more socially relevant tale, and it failed badly. Like "The Woman in Black," it lapsed into cliches at the end.After seeing the movie, "The Woman in Black," I read the book by Susan Hill. It's a modern classic and follows the well-worn traditions of gothic horror novels.  The tale is slow paced and reflective. The book is also very different from the movie, from start to finish.All in all, I think devoted fans of gothic-style horror will enjoy this film enough to want to own a copy.  Just be sure it includes the special features.And, for authors, this film is a good study of pacing, plotting, and what can make a story compelling, despite other shortcomings.  While part of that is a credit to the director and screenwriter, as well as the movie's visual design, I'd give most of the credit to Daniel Radcliffe. He portrays a man numbed by grief, with surges of frustration and plunges into apathy. It's never a one-note or two-note performance, though it easily could have been.If the producers had committed to making this an artistic, classic gothic tale, and incorporated more of the "hero's journey" structure, this could have become an enduring, five-star, must-see movie.Fans of Daniel Radcliffe will be impressed with the subtleties of his performance. And, it's still a good movie, if you're a fan of gothic tales or horror films.  But, it falls short of being a success for either audience.Get the DVD and make sure to see the movie with the commentary on, to get the most from this. The special features on the DVD make a world of difference. If I were to see just the film itself, this would have been a three-star review, at best.
summary: Not the book, and not perfect, but compelling

reviewText: A was blindsided with brilliance as I watched The Woman In Black. The cover art and title lent itself to a run of the mill ghost story that may be tolerable. And guess what? It is a fairly typical ghost story, but the film is presented with such rich grounding atmosphere and tight acting that the old fashioned haunted house story is revived without loss.The blu- ray disc is solid and takes the viewer into the perfectly replicated misty past of the Old English countryside. I had no problem getting past any Harry Potter shortcomings that viewers may have unfairly dwelled on. This man can act, and he pulled out all the necessary emotions especially holding to an often sullen demeanor.The film digs deep into haunted house history with creaky doors, spooky structures and amplifies it with modern film-making to create the epitome of the traditional haunted house. The ghostly figure of a female evil spirit lurks and she delivers real spine tinglers. Quietness becomes the enemy as the house has a creep fest around every corner.Great evoking of British mannerisms and phraseology abound. The film stresses aura inducing scenery while you wait for the outcome to unfold. It looks like good old Hammer films are making a comeback as the films opening provides the said logo. It's great to see a ghost story, that really is a ghost story. Thoroughly enjoyable from beginning to end.

reviewText: Daniel Radcliffe is on screen most of the time in this movie.  He is alone much of the time, too.  The haunted house in question is the quintessentially spooky house that is inaccessable parts of the day or night due to the tide washing over a swamp.  The eerie atmosphere is well kept and Daniel's really good in the film.  As one review said above, how many ways can this kind of scary movie tell the same story?  For those who expect decapitations and lots of gratuitous blood, I'm sorry, but this movie isn't that kind of movie.  Some of the thrill moments are standard, but if, like the other reviewer above, the only thing you're doing is counting the number of them, then you obviously should not be reviewing this movie. The brief glimpses of shadows moving or figures moving past a mirror get to you almost at once. NOthing is scarier than shadows that move.Being indelicate, Daniel Radcliffe's not a tall person, and in this movie that doesn't matter at all.  Still he didn't have to have a love scene with a taller woman or have to out-yell someone who is a foot taller.  It was a wise choice, because now we can just concentrate on the good job he does.  (There are long moments when there is no dialogue, and they don't drag - not for me, anyway.)Is it perfect? No. But it certainly is preferable to me over those slasher movies (in which I lost interest years ago.)  It isn't quite as surprising as "Sixth Sense", but the ending was not expected.  My real complaint, not addressed by any others, is that the dialogue in some places is slightly muffled.  I have some hearing problems, but this wasn't in that category.  The dialogue was simply not clear in places, notably Daniel Radcliffe's first conversations with his boss and with the man who eventually helps him (whose son has also died.)  Dan was fine, but the others were muffled, relying on the British mumble to get through.I'm glad I went, and my reservations are minor.  There were moments when I had reall chills from fright.

reviewText: This is one of those old fashioned, traditional Gothic horror films that is sorely under-appreciated by modern audiences. This is the sort of horror that sticks with you, that chills you to the bone and I think that's why a lot of people don't understand it or don't appreciate it. It's one thing to be made to jump by a serious killer, it's another thing when a horror film reaches you on a deep and personal level.This is true to form, traditional Hammer horror.  There hasn't been a good, mysterious and haunting film like this since 1999's Sleepy Hollow starring Johnny Depp.  I miss horror films like these and it's a shame that so many people today just don't "Get" this type of horror.Something that disturbs me about some fans of this film are the ones that think The Woman in Black character was doing Arthur a favor at the end. reviewText: London, the turn of the century. Widowed lawyer Arthur Kipps is sent by his office to deal with the legal affairs of Eel Marsh House, whose owners wish to sell it. He finds the local village folk uncooperative and fearful of the house, apart from rich landowner Samuel Daily (who owns the only motorcar in the village). As Kipps investigates the mystery of Eel Marsh House, he learns of a spate of unusual deaths amongst the local children and starts seeing a woman dressed in black watching his activities.The Woman in Black is an adaptation of Susan Hill's 1983 novel of the same name. It was produced by the resurgent British company Hammer Film Productions, who in an earlier incarnation produced numerous horror films in the 1950s and 1960s. Unlike most of those films, which were noted for their use of blood and gore, The Woman in Black is a taut, claustrophobic piece which relies on tension and things glimpsed out of the corner of the eye.The film's casting is superb, with a post-Harry Potter Daniel Radcliffe starring as Arthur Kipps (coincidentally, a role previously played by his on-screen father Adrian Rawlins in a 1989 TV movie based on the book). Radcliffe arguably risks more typecasting than any actor in film history, but his canny choice of stage and screen roles has seen him so far avoid that fate. In The Woman in Black he convinces in the role of the world-weary, grief-stricken father whose career as a lawyer is in doubt due to his growing disillusionment with the world. The only other major character is Samuel Daily, played with conviction by the always-excellent Ciaran Hinds.The director, James Watkins, handles the material well. His depictions of a village consumed by fear, the huge and rambling Eel Marsh House and of lonely and windswept marshlands are all excellent, giving the film a real sense of place. Knocking in at just 95 minutes, the film also doesn't outstay its welcome.Unfortunately, the movie shows its hand a little too early. Upon arriving in the village, Kipps is immediately greeted by fear, suspicion and terror, letting the audience know that All is Not Well. It's not long before just about every time we get a close-up on Kipps we also get some sinister stuff going on in the background, or every other time he turns around we get a shot of the Woman in Black hanging about for a moment. The first few times this happens, it's unsettling. Somewhere around the twentieth, it loses its power. Viewers will soon find themselves predicting when something 'scary' is about to happen and will, by and large, be right. The film does succeed in achieving a few genuine shocks despite this issue, the movie's second half is overall weakened by this predictability. Given writer Jane Goldman's solid form (Stardust, Kick-Ass, X-Men: First Class), it's surprising that she doesn't put more genuine twists into the script, especially given its deviations from the source material.The Woman in Black (***) is well-made, excellently-acted, concise, focused and well-directed. The film is let down by its script, which relies a little too much on a single scare tactic and overplays it to the point of boredom. In this manner, The Woman in Black is the film equivalent of the computer game Doom 3: well-made, great in short bursts, but a little dull over the long haul. It is redeemed somewhat by a startling ending, however, and is certainly worth watching.
summary: Excellently made, but the scares become way too predictable.

reviewText: The Woman In Black is a disappointing horror/mystery film mainly for reasons that surround the confusing storyline.Daniel Radcliffe of Harry Potter fame stars as a man who visits a castle out in the countryside for a few days.  The first thing that surprises me is how much older he's gotten.  Yes he's definitely reached the age appropriate to be a father now, rather shockingly.  Seems just like yesterday Sorcerer's Stone came out and I was enjoying it after high school graduation.Anyway the biggest problem is that, well a combination of two things- weak, overblown writing that makes the entire movie seem artificial and too Hollywood, and despite a solid 15 minutes of actual hauntings *finally* taking place 50 minutes into the movie, overall the Woman in Black just isn't scary or interesting enough.Perhaps Daniel himself starring in a movie like this is the Woman In Black's biggest downfall.  Most of us are familiar with the Harry Potter films and know what kind of magical creativity was used to make those films so rewarding and provide an unbelievable amount of eye candy using all the special effects you can imagine, but here... well, it's almost like it *tries* to recapture the same concept using horror elements but never succeeding in the same way so the movie ends up looking more like a weak imitation.  Also, a storyline that never really gets off the ground until it's too late pretty much holds down all the potential this movie could have had.Had to laugh when Harry walked into a room frightened and jumps when mud comes squirting out of a nearby bathtub.  Come on Harry, you just seen horrific otherworldly monsters- a little bit of mud during uneasy atmospheric conditions shouldn't hold YOU of all people back from proceeding!Oh, about those 15 minutes I mention above that is actually *good*.  This is when Harry, er, Daniel Radcliffe sees a rocking chair rocking by itself, apparitions walking down the hallways, apparitions roaming outside the castle, figures appearing in reflections and mirrors, shadows darting across the room, children lighting themselves on fire, toys making noises by themselves, etc.  This is REALLY excellent stuff however it all goes away due to the movie trying to tell a story involving the death of three children that jump out the window under mysterious circumstances.  I spent more time confused than I did satisfied.The Woman in Black is clearly more appropriate for Harry Potter fans instead of horror lovers.  With that said, it's not bad by any means.  Basically the first half is disappointing and the second half improves in the atmosphere and horror categories, but fails in the storyline for the most part.  I like the ending involving a fast moving train, though.  I know what you're thinking- no, Daniel does *not* fly a car into the world of wizardry with Ron Weasley. :)

reviewText: `The Woman in Black' is pretty much a classic ghost story; lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is tasked with travelling to a small, tight-knit community to handle the estate of a wealthy woman who is now deceased. But while it's obvious his presence isn't welcomed, Kipps makes for the woman's isolated house and finds he has to deal with something a lot more sinister than paperwork, and in order to stop anymore innocent lives from being taken - and, perhaps, to save his remaining clean underwear - he needs to face a dark secret that the town is hiding.It maybe a familiar set-up, but `The Woman in Black' is still a well-shot, spooky ride. Director James Watkins pulls out old tricks to scare us, but it works brilliantly as he keeps the whole film in a slow, tense, unnerving atmosphere. The story is shrouded in mystery, as they always should be in these films, and Watkins strings us along by handing out little clues throughout and the scares come more from the build-up, which keeps you on edge, and it really helps on the delivery. Daniel Radcliffe also proves he can shrug off the-boy-who-lived and, although a little young for the role, puts in a generally solid and emotional performance as Arthur Kipps. If you let it take you along for the ride, `The Woman in Black' is worth the watch, every ninety-five creepy minutes of it.

reviewText: When reading my movie review, I'd like you to please consider the perspective of an individual who has seen many films in his life - most especially the horror genre has always fascinated me since I was 7-8 years old. There is nothing like the exhilarating feeling of a good scare whether you are watching a serial killer storyline unfold or a supernatural narrative take place. Having had the rare pleasure, but more often the discontentment, of having viewed many a Horror movie, I have instinctively learned to anticipate the plot of a story or predict the scenes. It isn't only that I've seen so many films with a similar scheme, but rather that there a lot of film studios that are only interested in making a profit and fail to make a good effort at hiring decent screenwriters, cinematographers, directors and so on. After all, it is a business and financing films for a profit is worthy of concern.I'll end this involuntary history lesson by briefly acknowledging the return of Hammer films as producers of The Woman In Black - since the 1930's, Hammer has come to be known as a well-respected institution. Imitation being the highest compliment possible, other film studios began adopting a `Hammer formula' and churned out films like there was no tomorrow, unconsciously causing Hammer to collapse and shut down amidst the sea of Hammer "wanna be's". Marking Hammer's return to film from its deep slumber is the gothic supernatural thriller The Woman In Black.I would like to echo what has been already stated about the film - disturbingly moody, palpable environment, eerie soundtrack, etc. but also offer a comparison between The Woman In Black and The Changeling. No, not the Angelina Jolie movie, but the George C. Scott film from 1980. The most striking aspect of these 2 films is the obvious fact that both Radcliffe and Scott play widowers males still grieving over the loss of a loved one. What follows is the collapse of rational thinking through a fractured emotional state of being into the belief of an afterlife and everything that comes with that notion. Both films allow the suspense and scares to build to a crescendo instead of implementing scenes of gore or devices of carnage. Both characters become infatuated, almost to the point of being spellbound, by the mysterious goings-on respectively but whereas Scott is adept at allowing the physical and emotional out pour to connect visually, Radcliffe is only capable at portraying a sense of melancholy. Even at the end of the film, he seems slightly impassive and misses an optimal opportunity to come about full circle with the destiny of his life via his actions.Bottom Line: There is plenty to like about The Woman In Black and if you go into it armed with patience (the action unfolds slow but deliberate), the firm awareness that Radcliffe will not be portraying his trademark wizard boy alter ego, and a firm acceptance that horror can be defined in many varied ways (that includes Justin Bieber's music), then you will be handsomely rewarded with a clever, well fashioned film. Radcliffe has done well and I'm confident he will find his footing in the world before too long, but special note that bears mentioning is Ciarán Hinds who is in great form as Radcliffe's new friend in town.

reviewText: It's a shame that this atmospheric retelling of Susan Hill's superb novel is so bloodless. Both an earlier British TV film and the long-running London stage version outclass it in sheer chills. Less is always more in a ghost story, but in this THE WOMAN IN BLACK the reasoning seems to be "If one wind-up Victorian toy is scary, seventeen of them will be terrifying!" With apologies, no, it doesn't work that way. The central set-piece, Arthur's aural "witnessing" of a long-ago fatal carriage accident in the dangerous, all-encompassing and impenetrable mist of Eel Marsh is rushed through, but there is seemingly endless footage of a game but green Daniel Radcliffe wandering around the haunted mansion. The movie is way out of proportion, and the ending (SPOILER) seems to want to have it both ways, both gloom and happiness. Buy it for the superb production values and the sterling supporting cast, but this version of THE WOMAN IN BLACK will not haunt your dreams.

reviewText: What's it about?Young lawyer Arthur Kipps is a widower with a young son. After he is dispatched to a remote village by his employer, he discovers that the vengeful ghost of a scorned woman is terrorizing the locals.Is it any good?If you can ignore the barrage of haunted house cliches, this old school ghost story has some genuine chills. `The Woman in Black' is based on the 1983 Susan Hill book of the same name and is also an on going play in London's West End. The dark tone is set right from the start as three young girls having an innocent tea party, get up in a trance, walk to the window and jump to their deaths...woah! That tea is some strong shit!. But it quickly becomes clear that this movie isn't about powerful hallucinates, it's about a pissed off dead lady who hates kids. As `The Woman in Black's' vengeance is slowly revealed, so are the cliches; rocking chairs, freaky porcelain dolls, ghostly children, dark corridors and window apparitions, just to name a few. The thrills come mainly from a handful of jump-out scares, which are sharpened thanks to some nice pacing and lighting. Daniel Radcliffe is also sharp, this is his first role since `Harry Potter' and he shows some serious emotion as a young father and widower, he tackles the role with plenty of maturity and seems well beyond his 22 years. `The Woman in Black' may not shock serious horror buffs, but the jump-out scares will guarantee a close quarter nestle from your lady.Best bit?The dark ominous atmosphere stays consistent throughout the film.Did you know?The vehicle driven by Ciaran Hinds's character is a Rolls Royce Silver Ghost.
summary: Good film with some genuine chills...

reviewText: Hammer Horror returns in full force in the 2012 film adaptation of THE WOMAN IN BLACK, starring Daniel Radcliffe. A lowly young lawyer is sent to prepare the sale of a grand old estate, the Eel Marsh House, but unbeknownst to him, the house carries with it an ominous curse that has been plaguing the children of the small town for years. After settling in, Arthur begins experiencing horrific visions as the ghosts of the past return to haunt him! THE WOMAN IN BLACK is an excellent revival of the Gothic tradition that echoes the works of Jack Clayton and Alejandro Amenábar in their retellings of the classic novella, The Turn of the Screw. A constant sense of dread befalls the viewer as we are drowned in mists and shadows. Director James Watkins takes a timely approach to storytelling of his own which pays off entirely, and allows for many long, drawn out sequences to incrementally heighten the tension and suspense as we await the final shock in the end. THE WOMAN IN BLACK also focuses heavily on eerie effects which can be achieved in frame rather than destroying the fantasy through computerized scares. Daniel Radcliffe is amply equipped for the role as the grieving lawyer Arthur Kipps, and plays perfectly in to the Edwardian setting. One can only hope that this will continue to spark more ghostly haunts in the terrifying tradition of the Hammer House of Horror.-Carl ManesI Like Horror Movies

reviewText: Read the various reviews here on Amazon and you'll find that, for the most part, people were either very impressed or incredibly bored with THE WOMAN IN BLACK. Put me in the former category for I love a good ghost story and there are way too few of them these days especially in the movies. THE WOMAN IN BLACK does exactly what it sets out to do, give Daniel Radcliffe an adult post-HARRY POTTER role and craft (that word is key to the proceedings) an old school Victorian style ghost story in the tradition of M. R. James (if you don't know the name, Google him. It will explain a lot).I have never read Susan Hill's book nor been able to jet over to London to see the long running play but I do have the 1989 TV-Movie that was adapted by Nigel Kneale (of QUATERMASS fame) on VHS. That version stars Adrian Rawlings who, ironically, would play Harry Potter's father James in the HP movies. I liked that version very much but have read elsewhere that the author didn't care for it. Apparently there are wholesale changes in that version including giving the characters different names. It was well done for a TV film with one very effective jump-out-of-your-skin moment.Back to this newest incarnation which is a co-production of the recently revived Hammer Films whose earler efforts (THE RESIDENT, WAKE WOOD, LET ME IN) have met with limited success. This WOMAN IN BLACK restores the characters' names and is apparently closer to what the author intended as she has given this version her blessing. However it too has its own share of differences including changing the central character into a widower with a young son and beefing up a character (Janet McTeer) who somehow has a link to the beyond.For those of you unfamiliar with the plot of the film, here it is. Young solicitor Arthur Kipps (Radcliffe), whose wife died giving birth, is sent to a remote English village to tidy up the affairs of a recently deceased woman. Once there he is greeted with hostility by the locals and is befriended by the local squire (Ciarin Hinds). Staying in the decaying house that was her home, he is subject to strange sounds and visions that include a woman in mourning and a number of dead children. These are the children of the villagers who are systematically being driven to kill themselves by this woman. After arriving at a solution Kipps hopes to implement it and stop the strange goings on.Director James Watkins and screenwriter Jane Goldman have carefully crafted an old school ghost story with all the classic elements. There are sudden sounds, quick cuts, and an effective music score that help to deliver some genuine shocks. There is even a lengthy sequence in the middle of the film that runs for half an hour without any dialogue which will either have you on the edge of your seat or will put you to sleep depending on how you respond to it. After you have watched the film, watch it again with Watkins' and Goldman's bonus commentary and you can see exactly how well crafted the film is. The performances by all concerned, not just the principals, are all first rate and this only adds to the overall impact.The one sequence of the film that I didn't like is the ending. I won't give it away but it forgoes the central element of the Victorian ghost story and that is the power of redemption. Once the wrong has been righted, the results should have been different. It is possible to interpret the ending as a thank you gift of sorts but in the commentary the filmmakers state what they intended and it is that which I disagree with. Nevertheless I found THE WOMAN IN BLACK to be top drawer entertainment and I plan to return to it on several occasions. It can take its place along with THE HAUNTING (1963), THE CHANGELING (1979 - George C. Scott not Angelina), and THE OTHERS (2001) as one of the handful of great cinematic ghost story adaptations.
summary: WIB Is An Old School Ghost Story Not A Modern Horror Film
Title: The Woman in Black

reviewText: In "The Woman in Black" Daniel Radcliffe, otherwise immortalized as Harry Potter, plays Arthur Kipps, a struggling lawyer, on his last ditch assignment from his law firm to settle the estate of a friendless old widow. He leaves his 4-year old son behind for four days to travel to a remote village called Crythin Gifford, UK. Once there, he finds himself unknowingly walking into a legend and a legacy of tragedy and unexplained events that have had a stranglehold on the village for decades.The first thing to be said about "The Woman in Black" and its star, Daniel Radcliffe, is that this was a brilliant move by him as an actor to do something so quickly after the Harry Potter series came to a close, and something so different as well. Never once while watching this movie did I think about Harry Potter. Radcliffe may be one of the few actors who has become so well known for one character that will be able to make the transition into other things."The Woman in Black" is a remake of a successful television movie that came out in 1989. It is a ghost story, pure and simple, although, it is not simply described as a ghost story, because there is so much more to it than that. It isn't for the viewer looking for gratuitous violence. Maybe its greatest asset as a movie is its ability to turn ghost story in to mystery, slowly walking you through a haunting situation and revealing the secrets behind the strange happenings a little as a time, just as Arthur Kipps is discovering them.The villagers are opposed to Arthur Kipps visiting the mysterious house across the vast marshlands and Kipps soon finds out why. He is quickly greeted to a mystery and a story that holds the audience in place and never lets up. The movie is never slow and always interesting. Yet at times, some of the things that move the story along can be considered a little hokey, but that placed aside, the mood and delivery are effective."The Woman in Black" is a campfire tale and a campfire tale at its finest. It is a successful leap for Radcliffe who is trying to separate himself from being Harry Potter, and it is certainly a movie that will keep your eyes wide open because the things that haunt the mysterious house are not shy.

reviewText: Forget all the nonsense surrounding this being Daniel Radcliffe's first film outside of the mega franchise that is Harry Potter. Yes Radcliffe is in the movie and does a serviceable job in the role of Arthur Kipps but everything to me exists out of Radcliffe and to speak of him does disservice to the best component of the movie, that being James Watkins the director who creates and excellent amount of suspense over trying to use musical stings or jump scares to hit his audience. This isn't a classic haunted house film like Robert Wise's The Haunting or The Shining but its a fun little film with a flaw holding it back from greatness.I mention Radcliffe only in saying that every actor in the film outside of acting talent which they have seems more to have been cast for their faces. Its odd seeing Radcliffe playing a father sure, but Kipps isn't a character like Jack Torrance. Radcliffe main use in the film is to either appear haunted or scared which He does well. He's joined by the excellent Ciaran Hinds playing a local landowner who doesn't believe all this woman in black nonsense despite having a mentally unstable wife played by Janet Mcteer.The Woman in Black herself is a beautiful creation, a ethereal image that plays like English Freddy Krueger, a vengeful spirit who causes the death of children when she's seen in the town of Crythin Gifford, gathering the spirits of her victims around her as sort of a haunting troupe.As I said the real star of the film is James Watkins not to take anything from the work of the cinematographer or production designer. Watkins does pepper the film with jump scares from the Woman's screech to a bird in a chimney but He also tries the approach of John Carpenter in Halloween with hidden glimpses of the woman over the shoulder of a character or moments of an agitated dog to signal her coming. The film does use sound to create more measured bits of suspense included a bit lifted Susan Hill's novel involving a rocking chair behind a locked room and it works well. Then there's the house on Eel Marsh itself is a beautiful creation in keeping with the period setting of the film, a reclusive decaying mansion surrounded by marshes and a tide that cuts it off from town in order to strand Radcliffe.It all adds up to a really good horror film, one with a dark edge to its action and one worth seeing in theatres to get the experience from the sights and sounds created to drive the suspense. There's just one true negative for me and that's the ending of the movie perhaps put in the film for Radcliffe's star power, or perhaps the result of negative testing. Hopefully not spoiling the end at one point the movie seems to go for a dark ending only to have some bit of happy schmaltz that tries to lighten the mood and doesn't work at all. Watkins previous film Eden Lake contained a twisted bit of glumness in its finale so it feels like something to fit with the fact that the movie has Harry Potter in the lead. Thankfully though for me one minute of blandness didn't kill a great ninety minutes that preceded it.The disc from Sony Pictures doesn't have much in the way of great extras for fans of the film relying on an EPK making of and a bit about Daniel Radcliffe. Susan Hill pops up for a bit in the making of but the best bit bonus is a commentary from Watkins and Jane Goldman. What the disc has going for it is a superb audio visual package that works for the film. As I've said this beautiful looking ghost film where most of what drives the film are the images and the sound. Sure you could make a game out of all the scary sounds that are trotted out but there are other moments like a scene in a bog covered in fog that work well.For fans of gothic horror films and ghost stories this is a recommended disc an excellent highlight for the format.
Title: The Woman in Black

reviewText: There's a legend around the seaside town of Crythin Gifford of a woman all dressed in black hiding her face beneath a long black veil.  Whenever someone sees her, somewhere in town, a child dies.When troubled estate attorney Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe of the Harry Potter fame) comes to town to settle the estate of an eccentric client, he has no idea of the hostility the town throws his way.  No one will speak to him except to tell him that it would be wise to leave.  But he is determined to get the job done or else risk losing his job.  While staying at his former client's decrepit mansion cut of from the rest of the world by a marsh, Kipps begins seeing a mysterious woman in black and soon enough, a young girl dies in his arms.  As the sightings of this woman increases, the number of dead children begins to rise and Kipps finds himself in the center of a mystery that has haunted the town over the last forty years; a mystery involving the accidental drowning of a young boy tragically witnessed by the boy's mother whom the townspeople had successfully taken the child from due to their strict moral code simply because he was born out of wedlock.  His mother died in the midst of her grief and that grief turned to revenge.  Now Kipps has three days to uncover the truth behind the legend and bring about a close to the town's curse before his own son becomes the next target for The Woman In Black.The movie itself was energetic enough to keep you interested and really harken back to the late Brittish horror movies of the 60s and 70s.  The score by Marco Beltrami was creepy and helped added some much needed tension that the movie lacked visually.  But there are a fair amount of problems here.  The jump scares are numerous.  And while Radcliffe is a really good actor, I thought he was miscast.  He looked really to young for the part.  In fact, he looked like he was 18 with badly grown facial hair.  I also loved how the boy in the marsh body was never recovered, yet Kipps was not only able to locate it in record time, the carriage he died in looked as if it had just rolled in yesterday instead of rotting under the water and muck for the last forty years.  But the biggest complaint lies in the ending.  For a movie this grim, I found it a little too happy, a little too Hollywood. It seemed out of place and that pretty much killed it for me.  Even so, I'm still recommending it just on its mystery quality and because it's a simple ghost story that isn't complicated or burden down by too much back story.  Good for a rainy night.
Title: The Woman in Black

reviewText: At the tail end of the 19th century, Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) still feels like the wound is still fresh when it comes to his wife who died four years ago after giving birth to their son. Arthur is drowning in a depressive state that even his son notices. As a lawyer, Arthur is forced to travel to a secluded town to take care of the work of the now deceased Alice Drablow as a last ditch effort to save his job. Arthur is expecting to be buried in paperwork until the weekend, but the odd occurrences that transpire are a bit out of left field. Everyone in town practically begs for Arthur to return to London immediately as children continue to die gruesome deaths left and right. Ignoring their pleas, Arthur decides to confront the problem head on and stay at the Drablow's menacing house where his constant run-ins with the supernatural eventually take its toll on him.The Woman in Black is a horror film that I wanted to be good. It's Daniel Radcliffe's first movie outside of the Harry Potter franchise and he's been pretty enthusiastic about it in interviews, but every bit of promotional material seemed to point at the movie being your everyday, generic, run of the mill, "scary" movie. The Woman in Black does provoke your interest at first. The strange opening is a little hokey, but kind of intrigues you at the same time. The atmosphere the movie tries to setup is its strongest asset though. The heavy use of fog and old fashioned feel of the town does make the town feel like it existed in the late 1800s and the ominous score does its best to try and bring you to the edge of your seat. The Drablow house is the key to that atmosphere as it's absolutely gorgeous in this hideously grotesque kind of way. Everything is so dusty and creepy while the Victorian design only adds to that uneasy feeling the movie tries to stir up in the pit of your stomach.In the meantime though, everything else in the movie is working against it. It's extremely uneventful. Daniel Radcliffe reads papers, walks through a house, holds a candle, and gets a little dirty. That's the entire movie in one sentence. The Woman in Black also resorts to relying on nothing more than jump scares to try and scare its audience. There are four in the first twenty minutes; two from the same sequence and there are at least ten throughout the entire movie. Jump scares can be fantastic in small portions, but come off as incredibly weak when you can see them coming a mile away and are strung together haphazardly for a cheap effect. There isn't much dialogue while Arthur is in the Drablow house either, which is practically the entire movie. This was probably done to try and make the audience more absorbed with what was taking place on screen, but seems like a bit of a copout overall. Radcliffe has proven that he is an extremely talented actor, but he's pretty bland here. He mostly wanders around in a daze with a frazzled look on his face the entire time. His hosting gig on Saturday Night Live was more impressive in comparison.The Woman in Black will still be a very successful film as nearly everyone who was or still is a Harry Potter fan will be lining up around every street corner just to be able to see this movie, but the fact of the matter is that it just isn't a great movie. Its representation of the late 19th century is pretty good, but the writing, the "scares," and (most of all) the entire conclusion are all just extremely disappointing. The Woman in Black is a watered down version of last year's Insidious that will more than likely gain a lot of praise it doesn't deserve.

reviewText: Oh dear, they just cannot get this one to translate to film.I love this play, I've seen it in London three times and really, there's no way to translate the brilliance of three actors, very sparse stage design and an old theater. The story is extremely simple and effective. The use of disturbing sound design and ONE ghost is used sparingly and with very creepy results. It works brilliantly and always sells out. I'm clearly biased. My bad.The original movie isn't particularly creepy and this one is only slightly better. They should have kept this story pared down. The more superfluous embellishment you add onto a story like this, the more weighed down it becomes. I don't like the addition of the clairvoyant, a ressurected carriage, ghost children, or the body. It's all so unnecessary. An effective ghostly tale makes your mind wonder at what's in the dark? What are the motives, when and how will the next manifestation begin? You have to use more than just visual senses. Goading the imagination, sound and keeping the story tight are so important.Anyway; great sets, costuming, acting: that kind of thing. If you're easily scared, like spooky or love Daniel then you may enjoy this.
summary: Nowhere near as good as the play.

reviewText: It was nice to see Daniel Radcliffe, honestly a fine actor, land this dark role, and in a few instances the brooding interiors and misty landscapes did make for appealing eye candy, but it's an unfortunate commentary on The Woman in Black to point out that those were the best parts of the film. Toned down a few degrees this might have worked well enough in the classical sense as an English country house ghost story, but as heavy-handed as the movie wound up being, it suffocated under the weight of its own lurid efforts to frighten. I will not swing all the way into the camp of those who call this a bad film, because it isn't, it's merely a mediocre one that fell victim to its own ambition to be great. If you're curious about The Woman in Black, rent it, don't buy it, because I can't imagine you'll find much in it that compels repeat viewing.Let me put it this way...Creepiness: 3 out of 5.Setting: 4 out of 5.Plot: 1 out of 5.Surprise twists: Zero.Flinching moments: 2 out of 5.Performances: 3 out of 5.Overall effort and ambition: 4 out of 5.Better luck next time, Daniel. Hang in there!

reviewText: Is there another movie genre as maligned as horor? I don't think so. From gratuitous gore fests, silly slasher cesspools and remakes that rarely live up to the originals, Hollywood and even indie film directors have had their way with horror and they all too frequently don't deliver. Some directors even try REALLY hard, and offer up plot twists to make up for other shortcomings, and while I do enjoy a surprising plot element I didn't see coming, having seen so many horror films, I usually am not surprised as the filmmakers intended.Enter The Woman In Black. Right from the first moment, you know that this isn't going to be your run of the mill, disappointing, predictable scare vehicle. In fact, if you DO go into this one trying to find some evidence that you're about to discover some crazy secret as a plot twist, you will be disappointed. Radcliffe's character isn't one of the boys the woman did away with, back for some purpose or any other devious possible surprise. No, the filmmakers decided that a simple, straight up story about a ghost imposing vengeance to the rest of the town's children after losing her boy was just the right amount of motivation they needed to inspire enough scares from the creepy old gothic house and surrounding area.There are similarities to other ghost type stories such as the point when in order to hopefully put the woman to rest, he goes into a swamp/marsh to retrieve her boy's body to put with the woman in her coffin, highly reminiscent of 'The Ring' well sequence, but ultimately, similarities don't matter. There are enough genuine bone chilling moments to fluff the hair on the back of your neck for two movies, and the acting from all actors is far above the norm usually seen for horror films. As for Radcliffe and whether he's got the acting chops to move past Harry Potter and into more adult roles, rest assured he can. He himself is left to carry much of the weight of the movie on his shoulders for long periods of time alone, save for the woman and some of the ghosts of her victims keeping him company, and he does it brilliantly and believably.I also particularly like that the filmmakers were not afraid to rebel against tying everything up into a neat little package where everyone is ok at the end, and they also left it without a real 'hey there's gonna be a sequel' moment as well. Oh sure, they could do another one, but the way the film ends, it can more than stand alone on its' own merit, and I for one hope it does. This film was so good, I wouldn't want to see a hacked up rehashed sequel with extra explanations etc, etc. Sometimes, as in this case, the one film is enough.So, If you're sick and tired of the same horror song being played again for the umpteenth time and want a throwback to great old ghost stories, The Woman In Black is for you.
summary: Proof that its still possible to make a great scary movie

reviewText: The Arthur Kipps with whom I was hitherto more familiar is the English character by H.G. Wells, who later inspired the musical, "Half a Sixpence".This one, played by a haunted yet stoic Daniel Radcliffe with relatively few lines and whose large, photogenic blue eyes are as wide as they were in the first "Harry Potter" film, is the creation of novelist Susan Hill, and also English.Performing in this 95-minute horror flick, which in some ways is not too much of a stretch for him, the former child star, rocking a pair of sideburns along with his short but athletic build, plays an Edwardian era  widower with a small son(Radcliffe's  sweet little real-life godson, Mischa Handley), and sometimes seems eager, at times overly eager, to proclaim his maturity to the world. The short, pert chin of that still adorably pinchable boyish face, which once buttressed baby-fat-filled cheeks as it lifted in awe to inspect a golden snitch is now stubble ridden as it inspects grimmer haunted surroundings. Certain camera shots seem to echo and overly emphasize the message, "I'm an adult now, and I have the body hair to prove it!"The tale begins with the inexplicable demise of the three Fisher Sisters(Emma Shorey, Molly Harmon,and Ellisa Walker-Reid), who suddenly, under mysterious possession, leave off from playing Tea Party with their dolls and jump to their deaths from the attic windows of their parents' inn amid the audible screams of their mother.Meanwhile in London, Kipps, a struggling  young attorney is sent to the costal area by train to settle a deceased client's estate, called Eel Marsh House where a vengeful veiled spirit haunts him  as it does the villagers, whose children also become possessed and engage in suicidal acts despite Kipps' frequent and futile attempts to save them. It is of some significance that his four-year-old has  drawn for him, a little calendar, marking the days leading to their scheduled Friday reunion.His most relevant acquaintance at this time is the prominent citizen, Sam Daily(Ciaran Hinds, who appeared with Radcliffe in the last two "Harry Potter" films), and his disturbed wife, Elizabeth(Janet McTeer)who still grieves the loss of their son, Nicholas(Sidney Johnston), who would have been the same age as Kipps had he lived.As the story continues, the young lawyer experiences a mounting level of social  castigation from the locals and is also haunted by a beautiful and benevolent woman in white, namely the spirit of his late wife(Sophie Stuckey) who died in childbirth.Scenes of him sifting through the correspondence that help him investigate the case with the malevolent spirit lurking about reminded me of  part of the following poem, "Antigonish" by William Hughes Mearns:"Yesterday, upon the stair, I saw a man who wasn't there. He wasn't there again today. I wish, I wish he'd go away."The apparition of this woman( Liz White) who won't go away is later joined by the phantoms of her many young victims. But after gaining in-depth knowledge of the situation, Arthur, with Mr. Daily's help, literally gets down and dirty to bring resolution to the previously unsolved matter. But the spirit remains unforgiving, and she will restore everything Arthur holds dear to him in her own cruel way, creating a very poignant ending.I can't say I found this horror flick to be too scary at all, really. But Radcliffe's personal charm carries the story, and Director James Watkins provides another showcase for its young star's fabulous talent.
summary: A Friday Reunion and An Evil Reward for Redemption

reviewText: Daniel Radcliffe gives a memorable performance as Arthur Kipps, a London solicitor (attorney) and widowed father of a 4-year-old boy who is on thin ice with his firm due to non-productivity because of grief over his wife's passing. He is given one final chance to prove his value to the firm and keep his job: Go to the remote village of Crythin Gifford and settle the probate affairs of the rambling, secluded mansion of Eel Marsh House, whose tenants recently died. He soon discovers and becomes immersed in the macabre secrets of the house and village in this carefully told story.THE WOMAN in BLACK is the sort of thing I didn't think could still be done these days, a gothic horror story about a haunted house with a clever, original plot and mythos, disturbing images but no schlocky gore for its own sake, and above all, genuinely frightening qualities. The question of whether or not Kipps will keep his job adds to the suspense. The cinematography is first-rate, with bleakly striking views of the English countryside and village. The early 1900s time period is captured most convincingly. Excellent acting by everyone else as well, particularly the various child actors and Ciarán Hinds as local resident Sam Daily. Finally, a beautifully unexpected ending.

reviewText: I love gothic horror -- big cobwebbed houses, squawking ravens, rolling mists and mysterious sinister figures that are only glimpsed. "The Woman in Black" has all of those. In fact, this slow, haunting movie loads on the Edwardian ghost-story atmosphere so thick that it practically chokes you -- and while it tends to move slowly, it's beautifully creepy.Young lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) has a life in tatters -- his career is in jeopardy, and he's still in mourning over the loss of his wife four years ago. He's sent to sort through the personal effects of Alice Drablow, who left behind a decayed mansion set in the misty marshes -- and when visiting the house, he sees a veiled woman in black.The locals are also desperate to get rid of him, even blaming him for the death of a child who drank lye. And soon Kipps begins to understand why, as he unravels the secrets of the Drablow family, and the madwoman who lost her child long ago. With the help of his new friend Sam Daily (Ciarán Hinds),  Kipps will set out to stop the Woman in Black before she claims what's dearest to him.I haven't been too impressed with the output of the revitalized Hammer Films company. "The Woman in Black" is probably the best horror movie they've produced -- it feels like a modern version of their shadowy, gothic old movies. It's also not very scary, although director James Watkins tosses in a few jump scares (a raven, a faucet, etc).Instead, the movie just makes you uneasy. We're constantly aware that SOMETHING is hovering over this town. But for most of the movie, we only see fleeting glimpses of the Woman and her power.The biggest problem is that the movie moves rather slowly, especially in the first half. But for me, it's compensated for by Watkins inserting some truly unnerving scenes, like a hysterical Mrs. Daily carving into the table. And the gothic atmosphere is so heavy and dark that it practically drips from the screen -- vast mildewed houses, foggy marshes, half-forgotten letters and old photos, and a grey rainy light that seems to wash the colors from the world.There's not a trace of Harry Potter in Daniel Radcliffe's performance here. His Arthur Kipps is a haunted, broken figure who seems strangely detached from the world around him, except when it comes to endangered children. The only problem is that Radcliffe looks a little young for the role -- whenever Arthur is with his little son, he looks more like the kid's big brother."The Woman in Black" is rather slow at times, but the gothic atmosphere and a strong performance from Radcliffe almost make up for that. Well, I'll gladly take it over rotten slasher remakes.

reviewText: THE WOMAN IN BLACK (2012, 95 minutes) may only be hailed as one of the retooled Hammer Studios' 'horror-light' flicks (it's rated PG-13), it may be remembered only for its very beautiful presentation of a very hot adult Daniel Radcliffe. However, I think it will also be remembered for its excellent presentation of the modern paranormal-obsessed ideas about haunted houses.Not to be confused withWoman in Black [HD].In this sense it is a bit rife with anachronistic speech. Radcliffe is a young attorney who travels to a weird lady's estate to personally sort through her papers. When he begins catching glimpses of her (there's your "lady in black") and village children start killing themselves - well! - all I can say is I wonder how they balanced this to keep the PG-13 rating. But they did. I must say, they got some of the tension at perfect pitch, but the problem is it rarely pays. The tension in horror movies must pay off, otherwise it only hurts your muscles.Radcliffe is adequate in this, his most boring work to date. The majority of this film consists of Radcliffe (who makes Edwardian suits look extremely sexy), wandering about the giant, spooky mansion and looking gravely concerned. In a way, for me it is a treat because it is a return to the old Hammer days, complete with a tiny bit of that trademark "Hammer Blood" and Hammer's wonderful treatment of making scary horror into a rather bright, colorful Victorian riot. I love that when there's no senseless gore.What I do not like is the manipulation of children. Here it is used sparingly but it is used nonetheless. I hate that. Children should be off limits for anything adult. Have we not learned that yet?! Otherwise, it is a typical silly low-key British horror film and one cannot blame them for stretching an entire film to fit a rather small metaphysical issue. Perhaps the best of this film is really Radcliffe. The camera loves this boy as I do, and it manages to study almost every inch of him, from his coiffed black hair to his flat Tiffany-blue eyes, from his alabaster skin to his very fine form.I drool for Radcliffe and don't care who knows it! So does this film, and it offers him quite a few close-ups that I wonder whether he deserves or not. It isn't that he can't act because he is most capable; it's that nothing is actually happening and he gets these startling close-ups which I love and audiences love. But otherwise why do it? It borders on treating Radcliffe like a piece of meat. That is something I do not appreciate.One interesting thing this film shows is how relatively healthy Radcliffe really is. Emotional stability and an overall relatively clean bill of health is always written all over a star's face and body. When playing Harry Potter, there were times when Radcliffe was drunk, which he says fans can spot by catching the scenes where he's "dead behind the eyes". I'd guess it was because of his condition, dyspraxia - but Radcliffe stopped drinking some time ago and it really shows. He's 25 and he has a truly stellar career ahead of him, if he works instead of playing to any crowd.Luckily, that is just what Radcliffe does.With the talents of Ciarán Hinds, Shaun Dooley and Roger Allam.
summary: Hammer knocks one home again ... sort of ...

reviewText: I don't really like horror movies. I find them generally predictable and kind of stupid. And it moves at an old fashioned pace that may not be to everyone's tastes. I loved the slow build up though.There are a lot of ghost story tropes here. reviewText: If I were young, or hadn't seen very many ghostly horror movies, this might have been pretty good. But I'm not, and I have, so this was a real yawn fest.Here's the scoop. Radcliffe is a solicitor in Jolly Old. He's depressed because he lost his wife during the birth of their only son. His job performance is getting worse and he's in debt. His boss gives him one last chance. He needs to go to an old, dilapidated house in some town and straighten out the paperwork after its final owner has passed. Weird stuff starts to happen and kids start to die. He gets sidetracked and needs to get to the bottom of things.This is all so old. The creepy looking dolls, the creepy wind-up toys. The cob-webs and gloominess. Things half seen. Clues behind wallpaper. I can't believe they're still using this stuff. There are a couple of jump scares which, as any film maker should know, no longer cut it. The music score was too obvious. It underscored the on-screen happenings with a thick, black magic marker. There were a couple of genuinely creepy scenes in the third act but, by that time, it was too late.On the production side, they DID try. The sets, though old news, were done well. The costuming was decent and good attention was paid to period detail. The acting was decent enough, though I found Radcliffe to be rather stiff. And I liked the way they ended the story. They could have sapped it up but they chose a higher road.This isn't bad. Maybe it's made for a younger audience that hasn't been through the decades of horror films as have I.

reviewText: The Woman in Black film version pales in comparison to the book by Susan Hill, as it not only uses typical Hollywood gimmicks to get scares, but has deficiencies that lessen the creepiness factor. The biggest problem in the film is that everything is obvious, blatant and upfront, given to us in the initial stages of the film on a silver platter so we know what to expect. There's little in the way of true build up to give any heightened suspense; they just kind of rush Kipps (played by Daniel Radcliffe) to the house as soon as possible, and then the residents and locals try to rush him out of the house. Another problem is simply that we don't quite get into the head of Kipps as much in the film. Seeing things from his perspective as he sees them--as he slowly realizes the history of the house and the woman-- makes the novel much more effectively atmospheric, something not accomplished as well in this film. There are a few scares scattered a few places, and the story does come into focus aptly in the second part, especially as he finds out the woman's history, but mainly this film just felt too rushed and lacks any subtlety.I think you are better off checking out the other version of The Woman in Black,Woman in Black. That is, renting it, as the sellers are asking outrageous prices for that version.
summary: Pales in comparison to the Hill novel. Decent, but too gimmicky and rushed

reviewText: I picked up this DVD on a whim and watched it late at night...which turned out to be a mistake.  Normally, scary movies don't bother me, but this one actually spooked me a bit.  It can be slow at times, but I think the slow pace actually lets the creepiness of the scenes get inside you.A lawyer is sent off to a run-down house on the edge of a marsh in order to go through the papers left there, leaving his young son at home.  This is his last shot at working out at the firm, due to his clear depression over the death of his wife in childbirth years ago.  Once he gets there, the townsfolk try desperately to send him right back to London and warn him not to go out to Eel Marsh House.  But, of course, he does...The Woman in Black turns out to be a ghost with murderous tendencies and Daniel Radcliffe's character tries desperately to deal with fulfilling his charge as well as figuring out why she is haunting the place, and attacking the children of the village.  It was hard at first to see past "Harry Potter," but as the movie continued, the acting won me over.The house itself, filled with Victorian oddities and old paintings, and the lonely marsh its set in provide a spooky landscape for the story.  When the tides roll in, the place is cut off entirely from the mainland and this makes the setting even more frightening. reviewText: This is the second cinematic adaptation of Susan Hill's novel of the same name (the last was made in 1989), this one written for the screen by Jane Goldman and directed by James Watkins. As with many British ghost stories (termed Horror, Drama, Thriller by the press) the themes remain the same - just the locales and the names of the characters change. Not that that is a bad thing, but it is nothing novel and if such stories are your cup of tea - shadowy images in darkened house windows, incidental dead children, a suspicious group of townspeople, a lots of candles flickering out because of mysterious doors opening and closing at will - then this incarnation will please. There is very little dialogue and very little character development, but the locations are magnificent, the cinematography is glorious (Tim Maurice Jones) and the musical score (Marco Beltrami) is chilling. THE WOMAN IN BLACK is an elegantly creepy, atmospheric, British period style ghost story.When a friendless old widow dies in the seaside town of Crythin, young solicitor Arthur Krips (Daniel Radcliffe), who lives with his four-year old son Joseph (Misha Handley) - Arthur's wife Stella (Sophie Stuckey) died in childbirth) - and Joseph's Nanny (Jessica Raine), is sent by his firm to settle the estate. Arthur finds the townspeople reluctant to talk about or go near the woman's dreary home and no one will explain or even acknowledge the fact that he inadvertently incurs the wrath of a malevolent spirit, the woman in black. She is no filmy, gauzy wraith, but a solid black silhouette of malice and evil. The viewer only sees her a few times, but you feel her malevolent presence in every frame. Ignoring the towns-people's cryptic warnings (they are trying to conceal a deadly secret), he goes to the house where he discovers its horrible history and becomes ensnared in its even more horrible legacy.Along the way Arthur is befriended by Dailey (Ciarán Hinds) and his strange insane wife (Janet McTeer) and Dailey is the only man willing to transport Arthur across the tide covered marshes to the haunted estate. The story is basically dealing with life after death - in the person of ghosts who stay around to wreck vengeance for their deaths - and the many events that suggest that indeed there is a place after death is borne out by story's strange ending.Daniel Radcliffe manages to carry his role well (the designers keep him with a fashionable 5 o'clock shadow to prove he has outgrown Harry Potter) and the subordinate cast is strong in the miniscule parts they are given. This is a mood piece, a ghost story of the old-fashioned sort, and it doesn't pretend to be otherwise. You either like these films or you don't. Grady Harp, May 12
summary: A Smidgen of Edgar Allen Poe, Henry James, and British Gothic

reviewText: Badly advertised in the US, Daniel Radcliffe's "The Woman in Black" was made to look like some sort of Heathcliffe character living in a doomed old house. In fact the film was so much better.Set around the turn of the 20th century Radcliffe plays an attorney who is sent out by a London firm to sort out and secure the estate of a wealthy client."Go through all her documents to make sure we have the LAST will and testament" he is told.  The firm has a man on the ground there but they don't trust him.Radcliffe arrives to find the town to be closed to the point of paranoia and no one will give him a straight answer. They don't want him around and things like rooms reserved at the local inn not being available seem determined to drive him off. But Radcliff, having been told this is his last chance with the firm to get his act together since the death of his wife, is determined to see it through and if need be will stay in the house over night to get the job done rather than run the gauntlet of locals staring at him.The house is haunted of course, no surprise there, and as the night wears on the creep factor mounts. In an era of horror films full of gore, this one uses suggestion for more of its fright factor setting up scenes and letting the viewer's imagination do the work.There are a few flaws that are a little obvious. The whole thing is very "grey" to look at. Even the outdoor scenes are dismal and grey and the trick gets a little wearing on the eye. I counted two scenes with bright day light and they stand out. There are also a couple of very bad continuity slips. For example there is a scene where he hears a noise behind a door and tries to investigate. The hall way is lit with candles but no idea why? Did he do it? That is never raised. Or is the fact that when he returns to try and force the door, the candles around the door that were lit in the last shot are now out and he must take a candle from a holder with him. Not something you'd notice in most films but when this goes so far to set the creepy mood, these elements jump out at you.In the end this was so much better than the adverts made it appear and Radcliffe is well enough done that at no point do you think "It's Harry Potter."  If you like atmospheric haunted house horror films then this is going to be fun to watch.

reviewText: The Harry Potter franchise has left such lasting impact that, throughout the viewing of THE WOMAN IN BLACK, I half-expected Ron Weasley and Hermione Granger to apparate and lend a hand to their beleaguered old mate. A Hammer Films joint, THE WOMAN IN BLACK makes for elegant British gothic horror. It tells a dark tale of numbing loss and unholy vengeance. It's Daniel Radcliffe's first venture into cinema, post-Potter. And yet he's still dabbling in the supernatural.Susan Hill's eerie 1983 bestseller had already been adapted as a television mini-series in the 1980s and as a stage play, but the rejuvenated Hammer Film Productions thumbed it up for a go on the silver screen anyway. Daniel Radcliffe, all of 21 years old during the filming, plays widower Arthur Kipps who after four years still grieves for his wife's passing. His inertness has adversely affected his career at a London law firm to the extent that he's a hair's breadth away from getting sacked.Arthur Kipps gets one last chance to make good. He's dispatched to northeast England, to a remote village in which outskirts looms the creaky Eel Marsh House. In this ruined mansion, ringed by treacherous marshland and accessible only by a causeway, Arthur is to sort out a deceased woman's estate. But since this isn't an episode of SUITS, the spooky very soon emerges.A curse holds the nearby village in thrall, or not a curse but rather a vindictive spirit. Arthur's arrival is met with instant suspicion from the inhospitable townspeople, most of whom fear what Arthur's meddling may further stir up. Faced with brusqueness at every turn, Arthur Kipps presses on. And while he's so emotionally closed off that he rarely exhibits a reaction to the alarming stuff going on around him, the film does a very good job of jangling our nerves. The scares are of the make-you-jump variety, cheap but very effective and more restrained than garish. THE WOMAN IN BLACK does well in establishing its ghost story ground rules. We find out that the menacing figure that fleetingly graces your peripheral vision - a veiled woman clad in black mourning garb - is targeting children, is forcing them to engage in gruesome self-extermination. So, right there, a measure of tension is lifted. We know Radcliffe's character is moderately safe. And there isn't a child prominently featured in the film for whom we have a rooting investment. Arthur's young boy Joseph (played by 4-year-old Misha Handley, Radcliffe's godson in real life) is barely in it.Set in the Edwardian era (thus placing this story somewhen between 1901 - 1910), the film's biggest ace is the marvelously ominous set design of the Eel Marsh House. It's one of the spookiest haunted houses seen onscreen in recent years. As ever, in the auspices of a ghost story, children's toys very much become these creepy artifacts. I thought Radcliffe does okay. He plays a repressed widower and you may wonder why he doesn't panic more or just plain clear out when that empty rocking chair starts rocking or disembodied footsteps are heard or that distant window pane reveals a spectral woman gazing out. I think Arthur Kipps sees these unsettling events in another way, sees them as evidence of an afterlife in which he can reunite with his dead wife. One gets the sense that he deliberately seeks out the unrestful spirit. It's up to you whether this undertone exists and if it's communicated by Radcliffe's rather reserved performance. Also, with high tide closing off the causeway, where was he gonna go?THE WOMAN IN BLACK is rich in atmosphere and broodingly gothic. It's a restrained but effective chiller. Certain moments made me clutch the armrest. Perhaps one knock is that while it does maintain a thread of steady suspense, I think it fails in delivering that big payoff. It falls short of that epic grand guignol. It's touted as the most successful British horror picture in two decades, and so were you at all startled when Hammer Films announced a sequel, the story set to take place during World War II?The DVD's bonus stuff:- Audio commentary with director James Watkins and screenwriter Jane Goldman- "Inside the Perfect Thriller: Making THE WOMAN IN BLACK" (00:09:32 minutes)- "No Fear: Daniel Radcliffe as Arthur Kipps" (00:04:05 minutes)

reviewText: I was hoping that I would like this movie more, but I found it almost unwatchable. Only Daniel Radcliffe would have gotten me past the first fifteen minutes.I'm not a big horror fan, which may be part of the problem; I'm probably out of synch with what horror fans like. But I always feel that well-done horror has some kind of point beyond nihilistic unpleasantness. Often it's a very moralistic point, which you could argue is the case here, with the evil ghost being a "wronged woman." But the victims of her wrath are wholly blameless of any complicity, past or present, in her sufferings, and there's never any resolution to her pain or theirs.On top of this, the events of the film are less horrific than merely sadistic. I don't like stories that exploit the suffering of children or animals and the people who grieve for them. That's just cheap manipulation and disturbing on a whole other level--writers and filmmakers who do this seem more pathological themselves than their characters.The movie works very, very hard to be "scary" and it's so obvious about it, the artifice shows. The scary old house is a really, *really* scary old house...but why was it so decrepit when its owner had died so recently that her papers were still in probate and being sorted out by lawyers? Just how long had that house been empty? Then, not only is the house already scary, it's out on a sort of point which turns into an island at high tide. Why would anyone build a big expensive mansion in such a location, and why didn't it just sink, since it's surrounded by quicksand? There are lots of scary bits with ghosts (or visions, at least) suddenly appearing or sneaking up behind, but it's like a carnival funhouse. The ghosts literally "leap out and yell boo," and even as you're jumping out of your seat, you have this annoyed sense that you're just the butt of a practical joke. Since this is a movie about dead children, of course we have lots of Scary Toys, too. The contrivances are just too apparent.I didn't read the book on which this is based, so I don't know how much the scriptwriters are to blame. You could extract a psychological mystery out of this; the protagonist, Arthur Kipps, lost his young wife when she died giving birth to their first child. Four years later, he is still so consumed by grief that his son draws pictures of him wearing black and crying because "daddy always looks like that," and his bosses are fed up with him and about to fire him if he doesn't get over himself. But if Kipps has conflicted feelings toward his son, which might cause him to unconsciously hate children, the movie never implies this, so the sudden uptick in child deaths after his arrival in the village has no explanation. I won't spoil the ending, but let's just say it's a head-scratcher, and ultimately frustrating. You also see it coming from miles away.I only watched this movie because Radcliffe is in it, and unlike some reviewers, I think he does a great job. If he seems a little monochromatic, it's the fault of the script, not his performance. He works hard but he's given nothing to do except be grief-stricken, scared or desperate. He's choosing unusual roles post-Harry-Potter, and while that can be a good thing for an actor, he needs to allow himself more range than *The Woman in Black* allows him to display. There are some other fine performers in this movie, especially Janet McTeer and Ciaran Hinds, and all the cast does a good job, but most of them feel wasted. The movie is so grim, pratically the only emotion anyone is allowed to show is grief.This movie is one of the new offerings from the revived Hammer Films Productions, and it reminded me of a few of its earlier, sadder movies, in particular *Blood on Satan's Claw.* It's also very reminiscent of *The Sixth Sense (Collector's Edition Series).* But unless you're suffering from crippling happiness and euphoria and need to bring yourself down (and this one will do it), I can't recommend *The Woman in Black.*
summary: If you need an antidote for a good mood, this one's for you

reviewerName: Jacob A. Davis "Writer, Artist, and Theologian"
reviewText: With the film The Woman in Black, Hammer Studios returns to their glory days of supernatural storytelling, invoking the Victorian-type ghost story in superb style. Easily one of the most stylish, most chilling horror films of the last couple of decades, this one also has a heart (as the best always do).The story plays on both the cards of the heartbroken young widower in grief over his wife's death as well as the both sad and frightening vengeful ghost whose mystery plays out and creating a truly terrifying build-up.For his part, Daniel Radcliffe shows he can work as a reliable adult lead, supported by a highly experienced ensemble cast led by Ciarán Hinds. The film itself glories in its dark, broken beauty and makes one reminisce about haunted house classics like The Innocents (1961). There are also fairly potent visual reminders of other classic films such as The Phantom Carriage (1921) and Hammer's own Night Creatures (1962). The colors, though by no means absent, are mostly muted (making a great contrast in the few instances where they exist as striking). The music is minimal, unlike most American horror films that overwhelm with score from beginning to end.The story, adapted directly from the Susan Hill novel of the same name (itself also the source of one of the most iconic, longest-running English plays) features all of the classic elements of a haunted house story: the large, imposing mansion, the foggy, stormy atmosphere, a background in tragedy... it's all there. The tragedy compels us to listen to the story and to open our minds to it. We each experience tragedy and loss in our lives, and that seeking to connect with what (and who) we've lost can lead us down a path of desperation, but we don't know what doors and to what horrors that desperation can lead to. That is one of the great appeals of the gothic ghost story, and it plays out in excellence here. As a traditional ghost story film, The Woman in Black may be "by the book," but the book is as chilling as anyone could imagine.

reviewText: The Woman in Black is a pretty traditional haunted house story that focuses on atmosphere and the lingering feeling of dread instead of CGI gore and horror. If you've read the book, you'll be familiar with the unsettling nature of the story - a general sense that translated well to the stage play and here to the film. Susan Hill's book transcended the genre with the end of her story (which has since been copied many times) but this movie doesn't stay faithful to the original material in an attempt to spare the audience the downer.
