Title: The Woman in Black

reviewText: It's nice to have Hammer Studios back making horror films. This was the stuff I grew up on watching creature-features on Saturday afternoons with actors like Peter Cushing, Christopher Lee and Ingrid Pitt in their stable of stars, and a low-budget sensibility with a particular affinity for day-for-night shooting, busty ladies in tight corsets and pea-soup-thick atmosphere.However, THE WOMAN IN BLACK is not quite a horror film as it is a supernatural mystery. And it sadly doesn't have the tightly-corseted ladies, but as far as atmosphere, the cup runneth over. Endless mist, sunless days, torrential rain, candlelit hallways and always something lurking in the back of the frame.The plot of the film is very standard for a turn-of-the-20th-century haunted village story. A young widower (Radcliffe in a very mature performance) is sent on behalf of his law firm to clear up the estate of a wealthy recluse in a remote British town. The villagers in the town want him gone for unknown reasons, but he goes to the old mansion called Eel Marsh (sounds like a nice place, doesn't it?) and uncovers an unearthly presence and a mystery that has been taking the lives of children there for years. With his own child coming to visit him, he endeavors, with the help of a kindly man (the always great Ciaran Hinds) and his troubled wife (Janet McTeer, great in a small role), to give the ghost what he believes it needs to end its reign of terror.I'm always a little leery of ghost films because the cause of the haunting is usually far too mundane and that always leaves me wishing that it's not such a mystery as to why it's happening, and rather just have it HAPPEN. It lends a greater mystery and discomfort to the viewer and leaves us to ask questions after the film ends. That was my biggest problem with Robert Zemeckis' WHAT LIES BENEATH. That's also a bit of a problem here, but because of a nicely twisted ending, we find that their solution to the mystery isn't enough.Radcliffe really leaves Harry Potter behind in this film, and it's wonderful to see him really embrace this role. He's someone who is very wounded deep within his soul, and it makes sense that he would be more willing to explore the world of the unknown searching for answers. Hinds is once again great at a supporting role as the only man in the village who seems to be unafraid of what Radcliffe's character is doing, but there's a deeper weariness to Hinds as is revealed later. McTeer is wonderfully manic but not over-the-top loony as the still-grieving mother to a child long dead.This film embraces mood and atmosphere in favor of blood and shock, keeping with the tradition of Hammer Studios well. There are three or four really cheap but effective jump scares in the first act, and this is honestly the first film in years that I actually did feel my heart skip at some of those moments. Once that calms down, the cheap scares make way for a sense of genuine dread, which is something director James Watkins handles pretty deftly. Most of the film is very quiet, which makes the frightening noises that come out of that quiet much more effective. He also is adept at framing his shots. Many of the moments of the film look as though they could be gothic-era paintings.Sadly, the film becomes pretty sluggish in the third act as they feel they've found the solution to the desires of the spectre and do what they can to sate those desires. If the film had more of an adult appeal, I feel that this would have been more of a character study rather than a film of actions and consequences, but since it's Daniel Radcliffe, they had to make it more teen-friendly. I don't feel that those roles are far off at all for Radcliffe, having done a play like the extremely dark EQUUS, and they suit his seemingly perennial five-o'clock shadow and his intense and piercing eyes.Radcliffe is a young man who, even if he hadn't been in one of the most successful franchises of all time, would still have eventually become a star, and THE WOMAN IN BLACK is decidedly good evidence of that.
summary: Good hopes for Radcliffe in a post-POTTER world.

reviewText: Rated "PG-13". Running Time: 1 hours, 35 secs.Three girls (Emma Storey, Molly Harmon, Ellisa Walker-Reid) are playing dolls and tea during the daytime in the attic. Suddenly, they all look at the windows and at the same time, in a trance, they walk to the windows and open them and fall to their death. He must go to the estate in the marshlands to go through much paperwork to find her final will. Every page must be examined. A Mr. Jerome (Tim McMullan) is not cooperating. Arthur's boss, Mr. Bentley (Roger Allam) tells him he must prove his dedication to the future of this law firm. It is his final warning. Arthur's bills at home are overdue.Aboard the train, Arthur meets Samuel Daily (Ciaran Hinds) who offers to drive him to the Gifford Arms Inn. It is raining hard. At the inn, Mr. Fisher, the innkeeper Shaun Dooley), doesn't care for Arthur having a reservation and tells him he has no room for him. However, with the agreement of his wife, Mrs. Fisher (Mary Stuckley), he can stay in the attic. Yes! That very attic.He arrives at the Drablow estate. Inside it is very dusty and with huge cobwebs. While going through the papers during the daytime, he hears the floorboards, maybe footprints and other sounds. He goes upstairs to see what it is (I'm not telling). reviewText: In an age where the idea of horror is suppose to be one bloody gruesome scene followed by another more bloody and gruesome scene, there is a horror movie out there that relies on the old fashion way of scaring the crap out of you. reviewText: How would you view the afterlife? Don't believe in one? Don't worry, some of the people in this movie don't either, though they have reason to wish to. Despite the wishes, they're not sure what to believe in.Except for the superstitious folk who aren't warmly welcoming of outsiders. Most especially if they see the woman in black in the isolated house. The one over the bridge and throught the woo- I mean along the stretch and isolated by a marsh that can easily flood.That's where a young widower must go to prove he wants his job (while trying to find out if he can communicate with his late wife), but things don't always go to plan. Take, for instance, the children. Out of all the suspicious behavior, it's the children who suffer the most (sounds Old Testament to me, whatwith how it says anything bad happens in society, no matter what, the children get it before anyone else), the easiest to influence to committ suicide. Extremely dark for a PG-13 flick, especially when some of it is implied and only one is overtly seen and is not so subtle. Why would a spirit committ children to do unspeakable tragedies upon themselves? Watch and find out, if you can handle creepy vibes, cliched jump tricks done effectively (several were predictable yet still got me), and a fervent characterization in Daniel Radcliffe's character with his interaction with everyone (especially the one villager to actually try to help him out rather than try to scare him off).Though, it's not only the jumps and spirits that can cause uneasy creeps. There's also the local surroundings. And not just the paranoid stares of everyone who lays eyes on Radcliffe, there's also the structure of the mansion itself, which is downright jarring with the antiques, wallpaper, displace lighting, etc. The mansion itself is like a character that adds subtle unease and has secrets of its own.And the history behind the woman in black herself? Now that... is a disgustingly disturbing story all on its own, one worth the dark and twisted story it is in.Keep your friends close when watching this, and your sanity ever closer.

reviewText: Daniel Radcliffe has shed his Harry Potter persona in this scary victorian-era thriller.Radcliffe stars as Arthur Kipps, a lawyer who has recently lost his wife during childbirth. Upon arriving, Kipps receives a chilling response from the townspeople, except for Sam (Ciaran Hinds).Journeying to the remote mansion located deep in the marshes, Kipps begins to uncover a gruesome tale of death as well as the mysterious "Woman in Black". reviewText: For years I've been trying to get my hands on a copy of the 1989 made-for-TV version of The Woman in Black, which is both very expensive and very difficult to find on DVD, so when I heard that they were making another film version, I was initially excited to finally have the opportunity to see a version of The Woman in Black on film.  I was, however, also concerned that there would be changes to the plot and deviations from the original novel that would serve to "Hollywoodify" the story.  After watching this new version with Daniel Radcliffe, I can say that my fears were confirmed.  There were numerous changes to the story that took it in some wildly different directions than what the author Susan Hill probably intended, and these changes did not improve the story.  One of the best things about the novel is its restraint.  It is heavy on atmosphere and psychological tension and light on the stuff of typical horror stories, i.e. dead bodies, blood and guts, psycho behavior, possessed people, etc.  While this film does retain the spooky and ominous atmosphere present in the novel, there were so many changes to story that I often thought I was seeing a completely different story.The novel begins with Arthur Kipps as an older, remarried man recounting the story of his dealings with the Woman in Black and how they led to the deaths of his first wife and young son when he was a young man working at a law firm.  His first encounter with the Woman in Black occurs at Alice Drablow's funeral.  He is sent there as a representative of the law firm and initially thinks the Woman in Black is a mourner.  I was really hoping to see this scene dramatized, but the film completely alters the novel's structure.  The two biggest changes that I absolutely could not get past were the scenes where Arthur Kipps and Samuel Daily manage to pull the sunken carriage containing the body of Jennet Humfrye's son out of the marshes (like they would really be able to do this), then take the child's corpse back to Eel Marsh house in an attempt to reunite Jennet Humfrye and her son (this never happens in the book and is completely unbelievable), and of course the corny ending where Arthur Kipps and his son are killed by an oncoming train after the son is lured onto the tracks by the Woman in Black, then they are both reunited with Arthur Kipps' dead wife at the very end.  This was the Hollywood shocker ending that I was afraid this film would receive.  In the novel, Arthur Kipps' wife and son are killed by the Woman in Black, but Arthur remains alive, and their deaths do not involve a train.  The ending is shocking, but there is no reuniting with anybody in the afterlife.  My mother and I both watched this film together and when it was over, my mother said to me, "It could have been so much more than it was."  And I agreed.
summary: It Could Have Been So Much More Than It Was (Spoiler Alert)

reviewText: James Watkins' "The Woman In Black" is a superb, bone-chilling return to the freezy tradition of Hammer Studios.  Daniel Radcliffe (of "Harry Potter" fame) turns in a fine performance as London lawyer Arthur Kipps.  An impoverished father haunted by the loss of his wife during childbirth, his employer gives him a make-or-break assignment by sending him to the remote village of Cryphin Gifford to examine the documentation of the Eel Marsh House that belonged to the recently deceased Mrs. Drablow.Mrs. Drawblow was a disturbed woman.  Her child was lost tragically, not unlike the protagonists', by drowning in a marsh.  The locals are particularly unreceptive to Mr. Kipps' presence and he is shunned by all but one man, determined to help him see the job through.The pacing and atmosphere of this movie are damn near perfect.  Reminiscent of much of Hammer's later work (From Beyond the Grave), the cobwebs and impoverished area add to the suspense.  What really clinched it for me were the scenes in which Kipps is alone in Mrs. Drablow's house and reads her letters, the scary voice overdubbing and the creepy puppets moving all at the same time.  One thinks of a malevolent Emily Dickinson or something, it's just really fantastic.The only problem I had was with the ending.  While I won't spoil it for anyone, they should have let it happen raw without the fluffernutter.  That said, this is recommended for anyone who still cherishes Hammer's legacy, and just a fantastic horror film amongst the dross.
summary: A fine return to Hammer tradition

reviewText: For a description of the plot, etc., read other reviews.  I just want to say a few things about this movie...The Woman In Black (2012) is a remake of the 1989 TV movie of the same name and based on the 1983 book by Susan Hill.  I reviewed that movie last July and gave it 4 stars.  This remake is actually better than the original, a rare feat.  From my experience, usually remakes of horror movies are nowhere near as good as the original.  This is an exception.The things that this movie have going for it are the dark, chilling, spooky atmosphere and the genuine creepiness of the haunted house from the Victorian era.  You'll see classic components of a haunted house - cobwebs, paintings hanging on the walls, lit candles, a rocking chair rocking by itself, creepy looking dolls, music box melodies, and of course ghosts.  Throw in the thunderstorm and the movie feels complete.  This is definitely one of the creepiest and best ghost story movies I've ever seen.  There are a lot of sudden scares that might make you jump out of your seat.  There is an occasional dose of comic relief sprinkled throughout the movie.  The musical score by Marco Beltrami is decent.This movie was my introduction to Daniel Radcliffe (I've never seen the Harry Potter movies).  He does a commendable job acting.  This movie is a triumphant return for Hammer Horror.  Who can forget the classic Hammer horror movies from the 1950s, '60s, and '70s?Overall, this is a good Victorian ghost story that I highly recommend.

reviewText: Ghost stories are quite popular in England, probably because the weather and the winters give an optimal spooky atmosphere. The Woman in Black is just such a ghost story. It was first a novel, then made into a TV movie, a stage play, and two radio dramas before the release of this cinema version (which I saw on DVD).The story follows Arthur Kipps (played by Daniel Radcliffe), a young, widowed lawyer who has a four-year old son. He is still troubled by the loss of his wife. That has affected his work. The law firm sends him off to the North to settle the estate of Alice Drablow. She lived in Eel Marsh House at the end of Nine Lives Causeway. The causeway is only navigable at low tide. The house is full of paperwork that needs sorting to ensure the law firm's copy of her will is indeed the current one. This is Kipps last chance to prove he is serious about working for the firm. If he does not do well, he will be fired.He takes a train up to the town of Crynith Gifford. He meets a local man, Samuel Daily, who is quite rich (he owns the only car for miles and miles) and is friendly enough. The rest of the town is not so friendly because of the house's bad history and the local legend of the Woman in Black. She is mostly seen either by the house or on the causeway, but occasionally in town. Whenever she is seen, soon thereafter a child dies. Typically the death is a quite horrible one. Naturally the townfolk don't want anyone around the house. Kipps insists on going (to keep his job). As he researches through the papers, he uncovers information about the Woman in Black. Oh yeah, and strange noises and apparitions start happening too. And his son is supposed to come up on the weekend for a holiday!The movie centers on Kipps. It follows his investigation of the paperwork just enough to reveal the identity and motives of the Woman in Black. His character is well developed. His motives for staying are sensible enough and he is likeable enough that the viewer actually cares what happens to him. Developing an intelligent, sympathetic main character is critical in this type of movie. Radcliffe gives a great performance, subtle and nuanced without hysterics. He makes it more chilling.Much of the film shows him wandering through the house trying to look around corners for what just made that noise or what he just saw out of the corner of his eye. Plenty of cobwebs, dark corners, and creepy children's toys are made even more ominous by the low-key but highly evocative score. The atmosphere is great and delivers plenty of goosebumps. The story is interesting enough and the various twists are only occasionally predictable and always effective.The Woman in Black is a classic example of a haunted house movie, ranking with the best in that genre (The Uninvited, The Haunting, and The Changeling being the best).

reviewText: Having read the book twice, and seen the BBC 1989 movie version several times,I was entertaining high hopes with this new version of one of my favorite Gothic-horror stories.I was hoping that a more generous budget would do full honors to this little jewel of  the Gothic-horror genre. Although the 1989 version proved that intelligent choices in directing can overcome many obstacles, including a low budget. On the other hand I also was a little fearful about this movie falling prey to today's curse on horror movies:succumbing to the temptation of drowning the story in computerized, cheap special effects, resulting in tons of cheap-gore and gallons of blood, and Disney-like ghouls and monsters.As it has been mentioned here by other critics, changing the story a little is not a crucial problem when the essential elements are kept,and respected.The 1989 film version did a few changes, but the story plot was there, and it could be followed at a real pace.The script was intelligent and it worked.But this is another story...I went to see this new movie at a classic movie house from the 50s,restored and with a big screen.I wanted to do full honors to this new version.But,as the movie progressed,the horrific truth was evident, my worst fears were materializing in front of my eyes.There was no real story-plot to follow.I was in for a Blackberry generation version of The Woman in Black. It was to fast-paced to be nothing but a video-game,the scenes kept moving forward,as if slashed with a machete,unable to create a story line.And finally, when I was confronted with the exaggerated and ridiculous "house on the marsh" of this version, I knew I was watching a pathetic blend of 'The Adam's Family meets Stephen King' for the blackberry generation.From there on it was downhill, a movie predictably drowned in unnecessary and exaggerated special effects such as the bleeding-bed, and a woman in black so unsubstantial that it looked more like a Japanese-anime figure running amok the Adam's family house.The end was not only too much of a travesty,but a corny and childish idea,unworthy of Susan Hill's work.For those unfamiliar with good literature, or a good reading, this 'video-game' version might do.But for those who are familiar with real stories and good scripts, my recommendation is:AVOID this waste of money and time like you would the plague.For me this was THE WASTE OF A GOOD CHANCE...If you want your intelligence to be respected, stick to the 1989 BBC version.It might be too slow for those whose attention span can not survive anything beyond 60-seconds bytes,or nothing deeper than a video-game plot,but for those able to enjoy true suspense and a good literary build-up of the plot, the story IS THERE,and its good!If you like classic Gothic horror stories, with well written scripts and literary style, I recommend movies like:The Changeling,Haunted!The Reincarnation of Peter Proud,The Uninvited,and even The House Where Evil Dwells. And the wonderful literary ghost stories of Japanese films like KWAIDAN and Ugetsu,

reviewText: In the early 1900s, young lawyer Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is sent to a remote village to go through the papers of a recently deceased old woman. He finds the villagers oddly hostile, but sets about his work in the woman's creepy, old house. There, he begins to unravel the story of a mysterious woman believed to haunt the place.If you're looking for a scary movie, look no further. There are scares every few minutes once Arthur starts (stupidly) exploring the house, endlessly going from dark room to dark room while the eerie music and sound effects build to get-ready-to-shriek-levels. The movie has little dialogue, with Arthur alone most of the time just looking for the ghost.This kind of alone-in-the-house part is usually played by a beautiful, helpless, young woman but Radcliffe does a good job, coming off as serious, mature, and fairly brave. If you saw the movie without sound, it wouldn't be nearly as frightening, so a great deal of credit must go to the music and sound effects. Ciarán Hinds is good in a rather undemanding, supporting role. The titular character disappointingly resembles a mannequin in a high school haunted house.The movie makes the most out of people' primal fear of the dark and genuine shocks come on a regular (one might say, predictable) basis. I found the movie just a bit unsatisfying, though, because Arthur's character is so wooden and stoic and the story is unrelentingly unpleasant. 3.5 stars.

reviewText: "The Woman In Black" is great! This is how the story goes: Arthur Kipps is a widowed lawyer whose grief has endangered his career. When he is sent to a remote village to sort out the affairs of a recently deceased eccentric, it soon becomes clear that everyone in the town is keeping a terrible secret. Although the locals try to hide the town's tragic history from Kipps, he soon learns that his client's house is haunted by the ghost of a woman who is looking for someone and something she had lost, and until she finds it, no one is safe from her vengeance.The cast led by Daniel Radcliffe (as Arthur) is great. The directing by James Watkins is great. The screenplay (based on Susan Hill's novel) by Jane Goldman is great.The music by Marco Beltrami is great. The cinematography by Tim Maurice-Jones is great. The film editing by Jon Harris is great. The casting by Karen Lindsay-Stewart is great. The production design by Kave Quinn is great. The art direction by Paul Ghirardani is great. The set decoration by Niamh Coulter is great. The costume design by Keith Madden is great. The make-up and visual effects are great.This is a great slow-build of a scary movie that will keep you thinking and on the edge of your seat with your heart racing. Daniel Radcliffe is great as Arthur Kipps and proves that he does have a career outside Harry Potter. This is one of the best horror movies in a while and another interesting return to form for Hammer Films.

reviewText: First of all, Daniel Radcliffe is a first class actor. Not for one minute during the movie was I thinking "Harry Potter!". This was really my kind of thriller, I like to be scared by the story but I don't like to be nauseated by blood and gore. The people of the town are uneasy and unwelcoming when Kipps arrives, they try to make him leave before his work is complete. reviewText: Forget Harry Potter when you watch The Woman in Black. One thing has nothing to do with the other. Daniel Radcliffe is struggling not to be typecast, to establish himself as an adult actor, not an easy accomplishment for any child star. Radcliffe does a creditable job in this movie. A classic, gothic horror story, it contains scary elements without resorting to the gory, shlocky slasher stuff of recent decades. As Arthur Kipps, the young lawyer devastated by his wife's childbed death, he has little to do other than to act wary and frightened, and appear foolhardy enough to go where no sane person ever would. This film has many strengths, among them the perfect dark, eerie sets, the cinematography that lends a sense of black and white to what is actually a color production, and enough of a mystery to make the viewer wonder what's going on in the forbidding town to which Arthur is sent to work. Along with him, we figure out, step by step, exactly what motivates the black veiled apparition, and along with him, we trust that he'll be able to put her to rest.But there are weaknesses as well. It becomes a bit tiresome to follow Arthur through the dismal corridors of the haunted mansion, armed as he is with only a candle and an axe. Too much reliance is placed upon the sudden shocking revelation, which the audience learns to anticipate. The most effective scene takes place outside the estate, at a family crypt where Arthur encounters the distraught mother of a dead child. Most of the supporting actors have little to do other than to look forbidding and threatening, but Ciaran Hinds and Janet McTeer are superb in there roles as the grieving couple who, alone amongst their neighbors, offer some support to Arthur. The ending is a true shocker.As is typical, the screenplay is substantially different from the novel upon which it is based, so watch the movie as a separate entity. It's worth a look. I needed a drink to settle down afterwards!

reviewText: The atmosphere infusing every scene and setting for "The Woman in Black" is so heavy, unrelenting, and smothering, that it is hard to just watch the movie or delve into the story. I've never seen a film that so unrelentingly reminds its audience of its intention through such a thick slathering of motif, artifice, lighting, and gloom.Yes, this is a ghost story, a horror tale that should be frightening. There are long hallway shots in the haunted mansion that mimic Kubrick's corridors in that mammoth hotel in The Shining, shots that should build even more dread and anticipation than they do. The rooms are filled with so many oddities and antiques (someone really had a thing about monkeys, perhaps a homage to those flying terrors from the "Wizard of Oz") that these inanimate curiosities stole the scenes from the actors.The actors---chiefly the male leads, Daniel Radcliffe and Ciarán Hinds---all seem to be walking through the sets as though they had been dropped into a carnival fun house and left to improvise reactions and lines. The ghostly woman in black startles more than she frightens, and most of the remaining characters seem stricken with dread and grief, making one wonder why they did not leave this dreadful place.The plot trajectory, alas, moved in a straightforward, if slow, line to the inevitable conclusion, which suggests that the studio was more interested in potential sequels than telling a good story the first time out.

reviewText: If you're like me you grew up watching horror films made by Hammer Studios. These were not your run of the mill horror films but classily made films that featured some of the classic horror icons like Dracula and Frankenstein but in more of a gothic location. This was a world of castles and mansions, of men dressed in fine clothing and women in low cut laced gowns. The horror films made by Hammer had style and class and a certain amount of eeriness to them instead of gore. The studio fell on hard times but is in the midst of a return and their first major entry is a grand one called THE WOMAN IN BLACK.It's the turn of the century and Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe) is at his wits end. A solicitor by trade Kipps has fallen on hard times, having great difficulty in dealing with the death of his wife several years earlier during childbirth. His son has grown but Kipps' melancholia remains these years later. So much so that he's fallen on hard times. The firm he works for gives Kipps a last chance to redeem himself by sending him to the small town of Cryphin Gifford to the Eel Marsh House where the estate of Mrs. Drablow, a recently deceased woman, must be settled. Kipps heads out hoping to reunite with his son and his nanny on the weekend.On his train ride to the town Kipps meets a gentleman by the name of Sam Daily (Ciaran Hinds). Sam is also en route to the same location and offers Kipps a ride to the local inn. But what greets Kipps when he enters is not what he expected: a cold shoulder from all but the inn keeper's wife who offers him a small room in the attic. He receives more of the same when he contacts the local solicitor who's been handling the affairs of the estate. Given the brush off and a carriage to take him to the train station, he pays the man to take him to the estate itself.If the creepy factor weren't already oozing off the screen it does so in spades as Kipps makes his way to the estate. The mansion is located on a small island with a causeway that twists and turns up to it. All along nothing but the marsh can be seen, a gooey water trap if ever there was one, with plenty of sea beyond. The tides rise and close off the causeway throughout the day and the carriage driver agrees to return later to take Kipps to Sam's house for a dinner invitation.Walking on to the house Kipps is greeted by the best of gothic sights, a mansion in disrepair covered with vines on the outside and cobwebs within. He lights some candles and gathers what paperwork he finds and begins working. But noises within the house cause him to stop and seek what is creating the sounds. As Kipps passes from one room to another, we have the chance to see the woman in black as her spectral image lingers over Kipps without allowing him to see her. She's everywhere yet nowhere in this house and the director of the film does a fine job in creating the atmosphere of her presence without seeing her at all times.Kipps eventually goes to dinner at Sam's and meet's his wife. She begins to tell him things that will lead him to discover the truth behind the town's fright and the reason they want him gone. Her tale and other clues lead Kipps to find out about the sister of the Mrs. Drablow who was sent away while her son was adopted by Drablow and her husband. On a trip home one night, their carriage slid into the marsh and the boy was drowned, his body never recovered. Now when the woman in black is seen a child in the town dies.Kipps continues his work, dealing with both the house and its foreboding inhabitant and continuing to deal with the loss of his wife. The intrusion of the woman in black in his business as well as the lives of others becomes too much and he seeks a way to appease her and put her soul to rest. This becomes all the more important as he has no way of reaching his son en route to the town to possibly be her next victim.The movie does a wonderful job of offering us teasing scares that never go over the top. The chilling moments are found from start to finish, the locale's offering the feelings that something bad is going to happen and the acting complements the storytelling that delivers chills rather than one jump scene after another (though there are those). Best of all is seeing Radcliffe in a role other than Harry Potter, proving that there is a chance of his becoming an actor that can handle more than the namesake that brought him to attention.The movie is one of the old time scare films that doesn't rely on gore, doesn't rely on a hatchet wielding menace or a nightmare creation that sucks out your soul as you sleep. This is good old fashioned ghost story that makes your skin crawl while you wait for the next scare and that's a good thing to see. Welcome back Hammer.

reviewText: Most people who go to see James Watkins' "The Woman in Black" will be perfectly satisfied with it. This lushly filmed ghost story, set in a remote English village in Edwardian times, does precisely what it sets out to do, which is to provide a steady stream of gasp-inducing thrills to its audience. Daniel Radcliffe is a few years too young to play Arthur Kipps--grieving widower, failing lawyer and father to a four-year-old son--who goes to sort out the tangled estate at creepy Eel Marsh House in a last-ditch attempt to save his career. But Radcliffe gives a solid and convincing performance nonetheless, as do Ciaran Hinds and Janet McTeer as a local couple who know more than they're saying about the mysterious title character, who appears in the cemetery next to the house at unexpected moments. The thrills, when they start coming, come pretty much nonstop, and Watkins & Co. deserve credit for remembering a cinematic truth too often forgotten these days: what you don't see is scarier than what you do.As good as the new "Woman in Black" is, however, I still prefer the old TV version directed twenty-odd years ago by Herbert Wise. The basic story of the two versions is the same, but the details are somewhat different. In particular, the older version is bleaker, more hypnotic, and ultimately more tragic than the newer. The story in the older version builds more slowly, and the shocks are fewer, which many viewers undoubtedly wouldn't like. But the slower buildup allows the story's horror to creep more firmly into your bones, and the shocks--when they come--are the most powerful I can think of in any horror movie.Unfortunately, the studio that made the new version has withdrawn the old one from distribution, so that it cannot be exhibited or sold anywhere. The old DVDs, when you can find them, fetch $100 or more apiece. Fans, however, are still willing to pay that. It may be that many viewers, seeing both versions, would still prefer the newer. All I hope is that soon the studio will re-release the old version and allow viewers to judge for themselves.

reviewText: To tell the truth, I'm not really a fan of the horror genre, excluding the classic Universal monster films from the 20's and 30'; but especially not modern horror, with people being tortured and slashed to ribbons and all that (why so many people seem to love that stuff is beyond me). That being said, I found "The Woman in Black" to be a masterpiece of Gothic horror, simply overflowing with psychological terror and creepiness; in short, an old-fashioned ghost story for the 21st century.Susan Hill's wonderfully atmospheric novel is what sold me on the idea of this film in the first place. Before that, I could have easily passed this off as just another disgusting horror movie under the guise of a ghost story. The film's production company, Hammer, was best known throughout the 50's and 60's for producing genuinely scary horror films with lots of gore and blood. With the company's decline in the 1980's, it seemed that they, like so many other studios, would just go out of business, but in 2008, they were revived. "The Woman in Black" is the first ghost story that they have ever produced, and for their first supernatural outing, they didn't do too shabby.Moody and foreboding from the very first scene, the story concerns Arthur Kipps, a young lawyer from London who is sent by his firm to the rural Yorkshire town of Crythin Gifford with the purpose of settling the estate of a recently deceased client, Mrs. Alice Drablow. From the first moment he arrives there is a sense that something sinister is going to happen: The village is separated from the mainland by a causeway which floods over at high tide, and the house itself, Eel Marsh house, is surrounded by a mysterious bog that holds many secrets, some darker than others. As he catches his first glimpses of the woman in black herself, children in the village begin dying violent and unexpected deaths, caused by apparent suicide. Arthur's job suddenly takes a more serious turn as he begins to uncover the secret behind the mysterious hauntings and the true identity of the one woman who seems to be behind it all.While I found several additions by screenwriter Jane Goldman to be a little wanton (Zombie children wandering the marshes, two very graphic death scenes, a ghostly reenactment of a suicide, some very creepy Victorian wind-up toys, and a rather mad Mrs. Daily who rears her two pet Chihuahuas like children and claims to channel the spirit of her dead son), the film stays very true to the Hill's book and faithfully brings that same unsettling, suspenseful atmosphere to the big screen. There is no doubt for fans of the novel that this is the definitive adaptation, far surpassing the 1989 BBC version.Perfectly evoking the flavor of the old dark house pictures from glory days of cinematic horror, it's a great example of what all good ghost stories should have: things that bump, creak and rock for no apparent reason, flitting shadows, flickering candles, bone-chilling shrieks, and enough thrills and jump-scares to keep you leaping from you seat whether you want to or not. As the film progresses, the scares keep building, so that by the time you get to the real chills, you're so worked up from anticipating what's coming that you are, to put it mildly, scared right out of your wits.  A handful of scenes aside, this film is wonderfully old-fashioned in its simplicity, psychological effectiveness, and lack of gore. The real scares are built on our fears of the unknown and the fact that what you can't see or don't know is oftentimes scarier than what you can. Sure, there are some really creepy things that you'd have to be blind as a bat to miss, but I find that the moments of almost oppressive silence are the most nerve-wracking of all, a good example being early on in the film when Arthur is exploring the house, alone -- no dialogue, no screams -- just the nail-biting experience of not knowing what's going to be around the next corner. The fact that this is so frightening is even more amazing when you realize that most of this sequence takes place in broad daylight!Shot in a predominantly monochrome color palette of dusty greys and dreary blacks, visually, it is one of the most stunning films I have seen in a long time. The colors, or lack of them, go a long way into creating a bleak and brooding atmosphere to stage the story and perfectly enhance the inherent creepiness of the film itself. Even the style in which it was filmed, most noticeable in the scene described above, is quite scary: It puts you right into the character's shoes, and makes for a very visceral and haunting theatrical experience.Being a relatively low-budget film, director James Watkins chose to rely mainly on "in-camera" effects rather than touching up scenes with massive amounts of CGI, which aside from being costly also looks phony if thrown in too often. I'd have to guess that about 80% of what you see on-screen was what was actually filmed then and there, not added in later with a computer. This decision definitely adds realism, something not usually found in horror movies, and doesn't cause you to keep drawing yourself out of the film to think "Oh, they did that with special effects,".One thing that sets "Woman" apart from just about every other scary movie I've seen is that it is incredibly character driven. It isn't just about the scares; it's about the people, too. I find that when you truly care about those involved, you subconsciously invest a lot more in them emotionally, so that whenever tragedies befall them, it hits you that much harder because of it. I guess you could say there is an equal measure of horror and heart, something that doesn't pop up very often in this particular genre.While I've been impressed by Daniel Radcliffe's acting abilities in the past, here, he proves that he is well able to emerge from Harry Potter's shadow and handle other, quite different roles. He's not known for taking on easy parts, and for his first post-Potter film, this is about as difficult as you could manage. A 24-year-old widower with a young child, grieving to the point of obsession over his wife who died in childbirth and who is about to lose his job if he fails to make good on his current case is a daunting enough task for an older, more experienced actor, let alone someone who is only 21! There is no one else I could picture playing Arthur Kipps half so well, managing expertly to portray the sober, almost haunted quality of a man suffering unbearable pain and carrying responsibilities far beyond his years through mostly facial expressions and gestures.The supporting cast is all very well chosen, especially Ciarán Hinds as Samuel Daily, Liz White as the Woman in Black, and Daniel Radcliffe's real-life godson Misha Handley as Arthur's son, Joseph.The ending, which is different from both the book and the TV adaptation, has a twist that even I didn't foresee, and is either good or bad, depending on how you look at it. I personally feel that it was the only way they could have given the film closure, seeing as how they altered Arthur's back-story from the original novel. The only thing that I really found fault with was the new twist concerning Nathaniel Drablow and Eel Marsh House, which totally puts at odds the idea of the Woman in Black and her vengeful curse in the first place.Overall, after viewing "The Woman in Black", I'm still not a fan of horror, but I enjoyed this film because of the strong emotional core and non-stop thriller aspect. I'll certainly be purchasing the DVD to watch around Halloween, when settling down for a night of fright is far more appropriate!
summary: A genuinely terrifying film; Daniel Radcliffe is brilliant as Arthur Kipps.

reviewText: You have to be in the mood for a good, authentically creepy ghost story to fully enjoy the quiet chills of THE WOMAN IN BLACK. It's only after the story ended that I realized I'd been taken by something I should have seen from the beginning. At any rate, the ending did come as a twist for me--but in view of all the preceding events, it was indeed foreshadowed by information given about the title character.Daniel Radcliffe has to carry the weight of most of the film on his own shoulders and he does a very strong and satisfying job as a young lawyer whose firm sends him on a mission to a remote village accessible only when the tide is low enough to permit horse and carriage to enter. The story depends on the musty atmosphere of a decaying mansion full of shopworn dolls that seem to come to life in a nursery where three girls met their fate years ago.Radcliffe's only friendly neighbor is Ciaran Hinds, who helps him get to the root of the troubled village and the death of numerous young children. The extremes to which Radcliffe is willing to go (as in the marsh scene where he recovers a dead boy's body) are improbable, to say the least, but so graphically enacted that you have to believe it. It's one of the most suspenseful moments in the story. Radcliffe is willing to recover the corpse to give it a proper burial next to the mother, whose spirit is evidently haunting the old mansion.The surprise ending fits the story but came as quite a shock to me, although with hindsight I can see that there was some preparation for it if you paid close attention to the script.For lovers of Gothic tales full of mist, suspicion, brooding townspeople and dangerous marshlands, THE WOMAN IN BLACK is your ticket. Good production values are in abundant evidence. Hammer is certainly making a good comeback in the horror genre with this delicious ghost story. Fine cinematography is another big asset.Radcliffe makes expressive use of his penetrating blue eyes framed by bushy brows that confirm his qualification for more adult roles in his future.

reviewText: What a cheering prospect: two great institutions of British supernatural cinema making a good show of not being stone dead after all.Latterly consensus had it that Hammer Film Productions, having introduced the post war generation to spanky gothic horror, was a long time deceased, wiped off the map thirty years ago by the Americans and their ghastly slasher franchises (Halloween,Friday the 13th,Nightmare On Elm Street), which left nothing to the imagination, and nary a haunted cupboard for poor old Hammer to hide in.Hammer's was always a distinctly British pleasure: campy gothic mansions, busty English virgins floundering wantonly at the hands of glowering gentlemen vampires and tension ratcheted by a heady collection of instantly recognisable tropes: bumps in the night, creaking staircases, candlesticks, quavering gas lamps and pale, cassocked children with faraway stares wandering menacingly in and out of the frame, all girdled with a patina of sauciness.An increasingly thick patina as the years wore on: Just as Freddy Kruger was firing up the chainsaws and breaking out the hockey mask, Hammer was tipping into Carry-On territory. I don't think Syd James appeared in a Hammer horror, but he convincingly spoofed one, and you fancy he might have turned in a memorably lecherous Van Helsing had the dice rolled differently. Not long afterward, Hammer folded.All the same, Hammer remains a grand if not exactly solemn pilaster on the frontage of Britain's cinema history. There's an argument (which I may have just invented) that evenStar Warsowes a debt to Hammer: Princess Leia, Darth Vader and Grand Moff Tarkin are archetypes which may as well have been lifted straight out of the Hammer playbook. David Prowse, Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing were longstanding Hammer alumni.Thirty years or so later, it seems, like its own ghoulish progeny, that Hammer cannot die. Indeed, it seems in rude health, if its new production The Woman In Black is anything to go by.The film delivers all the old Hammer features in spades. And candles, self-rocking chairs, overgrown moonlit graveyards and macabre clockwork dolls. If I had to point up a reservation, I would say it was short a fruity Susannah York in a rippable bodice - but otherwise it nails the Hammer idiom for the twenty-first century.Effective and (mostly) discrete employment of CGI bestows the Woman in Black a gorgeous, stylish look, and the production design is magnificent, from the dark panelled offices from which struggling articled clerk Arthur Kipps is dispatched to the provinces, Jonathan Harker-style, to sort out the papers of a deceased lady's estate, to the majestic tidal sweep out to her mansion perched on a rock resembling St. Michael's Mount and as joyously gothic as any haunted house you'll ever see.Now I mentioned the continued prosperity of two great British cinematic institutions: the other, of course, is the beloved boy wizard Daniel Radcliffe, played to such memorable effect in the eponymous film franchise by young Harry Potter.Few film fans haven't fretted about Potter's chances of escaping the Radcliffe typecast. It is a weighty burden indeed to have played such a definitive character so early in one's career. These first post-Radcliffe films are a make or break for Potter's prospects of cinematic longevity.In that regard, The Woman In Black is both a good and a bad choice.Bad in that, being set in an up-country Gothic pile and having a supernatural context, it is hard not to read in some of the Hogwarts idiom: that Arthur Kipps reaches it aboard a steam train from King's Cross seems almost intentionally referential.Good, though, in that the Hammer style relies for its impact mostly on its direction, staging, lighting, editing, sound and production design: almost anything but acting. The film requires little of its lead: if anything, more is asked of the supporting characters. They must (and, thanks to nicely understated performances from Ciarán Hinds, Shaun Dooley and Roger Allam, do) project a discomfiting weirdness on proceedings. The unwilling hero, Arthur Kipps, must instead be a blank canvas. We are expected to project ourselves on to Kipps: that's how we become caught up in the suspense. Potter's admirably colourless performance is pitch-perfect in this regard - faint praise, I dare say - but if he is to lose the Radcliffe tag, this is the way to do it. In fairness to the young wizard, for large parts of the screenplay he is the only character on screen: there are only so many acting chops you can show off by creeping along an empty corridor.There is, of course, one character trait Kipps must have that his audience lacks: a complete lack of judgment upon encountering eerie phenomena.Say you're alone, marooned by tidal mudflats, in the grounds of a deserted Gothic mansion and armed with only a box of matches and a cocker spaniel. Dusk is falling, and from nowhere a vigorous clanking starts up in the upper part of the house. Popping outside to investigate, you catch a ghostly face at a top floor window out of the corner of your eye. You must not, as would a prudent audience member after the merest moment's consideration, make at once to the shore and start swimming for your life. You must instead take your box of matches and investigate, to the accompaniment of loud, discordant incidental music, even though you ought to know your matches will surely fail. The idiom requires it.This makes for a superbly thrilling visual experience. No matter how transparent the director's intention, it is impossible not to be caught up. There were, at my preview screening, professional film critics watching through their fingers. If there had been sofas they would have been leapt behind. A boy of 14, who had been a bit cocky as the film opened, migrated to his father's knee and buried his face in the man's neck.Kipps approaches a peephole and looks in. The entire theatre knows exactly what is coming next: a ghoulish face will flash close-up and an explosive scream will jolt the theatre. But when it comes you still jump out of your skin. This is fully exhilarating. The tension and release is orchestrated expertly by director: it is a very, very, good piece of film making.The ending is unusual and, I thought, a little flat, but on reflection I thought it deftly handled, though exactly how I don't feel able to say.So how to grade The Woman In Black, then? It is expertly edited, framed, lit and directed. It is fully cognisant of its own pedigree, of which it sees the funny side. It does feel short a vulnerable fruity maiden or two. But by comparison with Rebecca Hall and Dominic West's recent The Awakening]] - in concept a very similar film - it is vastly superior. It is no Citizen Kane, but nor is it trying to be. That is not a sensible standard to hold it against. And it represents a sure first step in the emancipation of Harold Potter.Reason enough for a full slate.Go see.Olly Buxton
summary: A first step in the emancipation of Harold Potter

reviewText: A strong 4 to 4 and 1/2 star movie. Not the scariest, not the most original, but a fine addition into the horror/thriller genre.The Woman In Black is a very dark, atmospheric horror. Beautiful settings are used to great effect in creating an unsettling mood throughout the picture. The acting is good (but might require some subtitles at times for some deep British accents) and the special effects are also well done. The lighting was also appropriate for each individual scene. It was dark enough to create an uneasy mood, but light enough to see what was actually happening. Lighting is one of my pet peeves, but this movie pulled it off.So I have to mention the flaws..... The story is good, but is mostly recycled ideas taken from other previous titles. I don't take away that many points for that though as it is rather difficult to scribe a completely original story in this day and age. It also changes these ideas up just enough to make the story its own. The only other knock against this film I could think of would be that it is rather slow at times. This is used to ramp up the mood in some areas, but can become rather dry in others. Still, the movies pace is pretty reasonable, which is why I still gave it such a strong mark.In all, a surprising entry into the world of horror. It won't scare the pants off of you, but you'll get tension and, possibly, a few jumps!

reviewText: This is finely told horror story, set in last century's rural English countryside.  Daniel Redcliff plays a young attorney Arthur, a widower for several years after his wife dies giving birth to their first child Joseph.  His love for his wife was so strong that even time does not seem to be able to erase his memory of her.  It is as if the more time passes by, the more he misses her.  It is the young boy that keeps him going.Arthur's employer is loosing patience with Arthur's melancholy mood that shows so well on screen with Redcliffe's dark hair and his pale, pale skin.  It is as if young attorney's sorrow is bad for business and only if young Arthur can close sale on the house of the recently deceased client, he can resurrect his career.  So the story begins.  Arthur finds himself in a remote village where everyone seems less than thrilled to see him.  With his arrival to the village, children die mysteriously in the most gruesome deaths unbecoming of their innocent lives.  Arthur is deeply affected with the experiences since he has a child himself.  So the story turns the ghost story of horror of sort.  A deceased mother separted from her child who also died (but without a proper burial) is reliesing her vengeance.  But what striked me in this film is the way she expressed her gratitude to Arthur once Arthur reunites her with her dead son.  The end of the movie made me cry.  I was both happy and sad and I just broke down.

reviewText: When the movie starts the first thing that I notice is the logo for the new Hammer film productions. Hammer studios, if you do know, were a British film company that in the 40's and 50's specialized in film noir, science fiction and other modest genre pictures, but there great success and ultimate legacy would be built upon there gothic horror tales that they made in the late 50's through the mid-70's. Helping to cement the careers of stars such as Christopher Lee, Peter Cushing, Oliver Reed, Herbert Lom, Michael Gough, Hazel Court, Ingrid Pitt, Barbara Shelley, and directors Terence Fisher and Freddie Francis. Like the revived Eailing studios (droll British comedy) and Amicus films (anthology horror movies), the names alone have returned in an attempt to reclaim some of the past glories by using a signature still half heartily remembered by fans of movies of yesteryear, happily Hammer is still leading the way in quality fright films.The Woman in Black is the most overt return to their gothic roots, telling a ghost story that lives in the morbid tell tale hearts and fractured minds of misguided youths from days of ole. In other words, this is my terrain, these are the scary stories we are told around camp fires or experience on a Saturday matinee television show, before we would find the more graphic shockers of late night. It's a return to innocence, while letting the goose flesh crawl up on our arms.Set in the Edwardian era and starring former Harry Potter Daniel Radcliffe, here making a fine transition to more mature roles, and Irish character actor Ciaran Hinds, in parts that could easily have been played by Reed and Cushing a few decades back.  Based on Susan Hill's novel, previously filmed for British TV in 1989, with a sequel already in the works. I missed this one in theaters last February, but am grateful that I caught up with it now that it is out on DVD, other than an unnecessary sappy ending, this is good old fashion scary material. Just after seeing the pathetic Apartment 143, here's a scream fest to worm the cockles of my still beating heart.Thanks to no undue gore or torture here, but there are a few good jolts and a nicely scary atmosphere, plus one of the creepiest, but simple final shots in quiet a long time. This is a nightmare suitable for the whole family, and it's well worth the sleepless night.Check out my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

reviewText: *A Brief Note to Readers: If you find this review "not helpful", please take a moment to tell me why in the comment section. Thank you.*Stories about vengeful spirits never fail to fascinate, and during one of the bleakest months of the year, the release of "The Woman In Black" is welcome entertainment for a bored and mostly housebound populace.  Adapted from a horror fiction novel originally published in 1983, author Susan Hill's tale comes to life on screen, raising hairs on the backs of audiences' necks in new and disturbing ways.Arthur Kipps is a sad man.  Even his four-year old son Joseph draws pictures of him with frowns.  His melancholy stems from the loss of his wife Stella, the joy of their son's birth forever marred by her death after a difficult labor and delivery.  So when the law firm under which he is employed assigns him to the estate of one Alice Drablow, it is a convenient distraction and a solution to recent financial troubles.  Surmising he can put her affairs in order in just a few days time, he surpasses his deadline after encountering horrendous piles of disorganized papers as well as strange sounds and voices within Eel Marsh House, Drablow's former home.  Things quickly go from bad to worse when Arthur begins seeing a woman in a black dress in the house and on the grounds, the deaths of several children coinciding with her appearances. Faced with angry, superstitious townspeople and an unraveling mystery, Arthur's problems, once inconsequential, become the stuff of nightmares."The Woman In Black" is, in a word, creepy, director James Watkins achieving the tale's ubiquitous gloom in many ways.  The archaic town that Arthur visits is comprised of dank and mossy stone structures populated by frowning denizens.  Costumes are simple and drab, moors are perpetually misty, the marshland is black and oily, and the film is punctuated by lots of beauteous stills of a roiling gray sea.  Porcelain dolls and tattered antique toys are always good for upping the creep factor and Watkins utilizes them to full effect, their wide glassy eyes engulfing the camera lens, unsettling the viewer with their unblinking and penetrating stares.  The foreboding of Eel Marsh House comes to life, its creaky floorboards, dirty and faded wallpaper, and cobwebs adorning every picture, chandelier and wall sconce sure to thrill fans of Susan Hill's novel.  What will make the biggest impression, of course, is the incarnation of the restless and vengeful spirit of the movie's title, one that slinks through the shadows in the background, whose raspy breaths reverberate through the hallways and rafters, and whose dark silhouette comes skulking (sometimes shrieking) out of the darkness time and time again.With the exception of its star player and fellow Harry Potter alumnus Ciarán Hinds, the movie is cast with actors largely unknown to American audiences.  Radcliffe, in his first role since the conclusion of the Harry Potter series, could have been judged on his potential as a leading man but the role of Arthur Kipps doesn't allow him to exhibit his range.  He is instead restricted to long somber gazes and a handful of moments of wide-eyed terror, a performance in favor with the film's ambiance and tempo.  The supporting players are on par with their A-list co-star, Hinds the biggest standout for his affecting portrayal of Sam Daily, a man whose life has been torn apart in more ways than one after the untimely death of his young son Nicolas.As with most films of its ilk, "The Woman In Black" has its share of scares, the amalgam of music, sound effects, and on-screen action creating moments that make the audience jump out of their seats in fright.  Thankfully Watkins doesn't overdo it, his translation of Hill's tale doing most of the hair-raising work.  It is an admirable adaptation, though I'm sure some readers will take issue with the changes that have been made, the finale in particular.  If you haven't read Hill's novel (I didn't) and love a good ghost story, it's recommended.  If you have read the book and you often find that adaptations of books you've read don't meet your expectations, you're better off passing this one up or at least waiting until it's available on home video.

reviewText: Arthur Kipps is a lawyer in London whose wife has died in childbirth.  He has a four year old son and a nanny for him. However, he is in danger of losing his job at his law firm because apparently he has done nothing but mope around for the last four years. He is given one last chance to redeem himself, to go to a remote village and Eel Marsh House, where the owner has died, and sort out her many papers.He meets a man, Samuel Daily, on the train on the way there, and despite Arthur's very rarely opening his mouth to speak (ever), Samuel becomes his one ally in the town.  Arthur goes to Eel Marsh house to look for, and at the papers of this woman, and get them in order and locate her will.  How he is expected to do this, I do not understand, because even in the daylight, with candles, that place is dark as a cave.The important papers (birth and death certificates, adoption papers) are placed conveniently on top so that Arthur finds out what he needs to know right away - about the ghost, The Woman In Black (what wearing black has to do with anything they don't say). Every time he goes to the house, there is always a lot of unexplained sights and sounds, which never faze Arthur in the least. He's still just so stunned from losing his wife four years ago.The ghost, Jennet, really does seem to be taking her anger out on the wrong people. After so many deaths, you'd think they'd move away or hire an exorcist or something. As is usual in these movies, what the living person thinks/hopes/believes/is sure will appease the out of control ghost does not work. I didn't really care about any of these silly characters, and watching Arthur go from being covered in mud/dirt/or soaking wet to being dry and spotless wearing the same clothes, was irritating.Something that perturbed me: on the adoption papers those involved are referred to as Mr., Mrs., and Ms. (the unmarried ghost). But from all the period British novels I've read, there was no use of "Ms." back then and periods after honorifics such as Mr, Mrs or Dr were not used, and still are not. Jennet should have been referred to as "Miss" on the adoption paper.Janet McTeer was wasted, but I guess it's a paycheck.

reviewText: There are two kinds of horror films.  The first depends for its scares on graphic gore, unrestrained violence, and blood -- lots of it.  The second relies more on mood and an escalating sense of terror than gruesome images to get under the skin.  "The Woman in Black" falls into the second category.  It's a film rich in atmosphere that takes its time getting underway but, once it kicks in, never lets go.In pre-World War I England, Arthur Kipps (Daniel Radcliffe), a young London lawyer with a small son, is grieving over his dead wife.  His employer is fed up with Arthur's dour attitude and sends him to Yorkshire to handle the sale of an estate.  Arthur is warned that this will be his last chance to distinguish himself for the firm.Arriving after a long journey, Arthur is met and befriended by a local squire, Daily (Ciaran Hinds), though the other townsfolk are not thrilled with the visit of an outsider.  Arthur is brought to the house of the deceased, which lies quite a distance from town.  It is the textbook example of the House of Gloom -- grey, run down, surrounded by overgrown shrubbery, broken gates marking its entrance -- a place that immediately foreshadows bad things to come.For much of the movie, Arthur is alone in the house -- or is he?  Many of the trappings of a traditional ghost story are here -- the rainstorm, shadowy corridors, a dog barking at something not seen, an endless number of rooms, each with creepy and unsettling contents.  And then there are the sightings: a darkly attired female figure, a face at a window, a fresh handprint on a window, a corpse rising from a muddy grave.  Whether these are real or only figments of Arthur's imagination is left to speculation -- at least for a while."The Woman in Black" is from Hammer Studios, famous for a series of highly profitable Technicolor horror films made between 1957 and the early 70's.  Those features always had great production values and good actors, giving them far more style than their competitors.  "The Woman in Black" is true to that tradition.  Instead of a collection of young and pretty 20-somethings who will be disposed of in messy ways, it boasts a first-rate cast.Mr. Radcliffe's character is the focus of the movie and he is totally convincing as the lawyer hoping to make good while under a cloud of depression over the loss of his beloved wife.  He infuses his performance with a sad determination, as if he is running a track meet with his feet encased in cement blocks.  He forges on, knowing his livelihood depends on successfully delving through a myriad of papers, settling the estate, and seeing to the sale of the house.  Yet he misses his wife and the life they had together.  His Arthur Kipps is as far removed from Harry Potter as Hamlet is from the Nutty Professor.Mr. Hinds's Squire Daily is on hand mostly to provide balance to the inhospitable townsfolk, who would be equally at home carrying torches up a hill in a Frankenstein movie.  He prides himself on not being superstitious and refuses to believe the many deaths of children in town are anything more than unfortunate coincidence.  He also provides some exposition, filling us in on what happened in that gloomy house and why Arthur will undoubtedly fail to find a local buyer.  Hinds has a patrician look and never smiles. He suggests a careworn aristocrat who has seen much and prefers to trust his senses to belief in the otherworldly.Janet McTeer appears briefly, but unforgettably, as Mrs. Daily, a woman who is either an amusing eccentric or a looney, depending on how you interpret her actions.  Ms. McTeer adds bizarre contrast to a film in which the expression of choice appears to be glumness.  Dressed in frills and smiling pleasantly, she enjoys hosting Arthur for dinner.  It's not until we see some of her odd habits that we realize she may have a few cards missing from her deck.Director James Watkins has fashioned an entertaining horror film.  It's the kind of movie those who are turned off by bloody mayhem can embrace, since it's more about dread and terror than horror.  We experience the house and its history through the eyes of Arthur Kipps.  Watkins knows how to use sound and silence to enhance mood.  Long stretches of silence will precede a loud noise that will make us jump, but those stretches of silence are filled with suspense and anticipation.  We know that something -- anything -- might happen unexpectedly.Ample credit must be given to those responsible for the film's creepy milieu.  Art director Paul Ghirardani, production designer Kave Quinn, and set decorator Niamh Coulter have decorated every nook and cranny of the old manor house with Victorian furnishings, faded paintings, large carved cabinets, countless  candles, cobwebs, and eerie old wind-up toys.  One can almost smell the mustiness.Rated PG-13, "The Woman in Black" takes itself seriously and never resorts to self-deprecation.  The characters behave intelligently and have actual motivations.  It is in the league of Jack Clayton's "The Innocents" or Robert Wise's creaky-old-house melodrama, "The Haunting."  Like those earlier films, it shows what happens when a person is confronted with the supernatural and reality seems to spin wildly out of control.

reviewText: Of all the Harry Potter alumni, Daniel Radcliffe is probably in the most tenuous position now that the blockbuster franchise has ended it's decade long run. He's dabbled in other projects outside of the boy wizard's adventures before, and has generally shown to be a talented and more than capable actor. But he's also most likely to be pigeonholed, with people unable to accept him as anything other than a kid with a magic wand and pet owl. Even so, he's still in a better position than poor Rupert Grint. So what's the best decision Radcliffe can make? To star in another film that has him dealing with big houses and supernatural forces. Probably not the wisest move, and his Harry Potter fans who follow him into the tedious The Woman in Black may start wishing for someone to cast a spell and speed up time.Based on a Susan Collin's dreary but effective novel, the deliberate pacing is one that plays out better on the printed page than on screen. Daniel Radcliffe plays Arthur Kipps, a gloomy lawyer struggling to cope with the death of his wife, who passed tragically years earlier after giving birth to their son. Arthur apparently hasn't smiled since, so much so that his son draws depressing pictures of his Dad(to comical effect). His demeanor is so bleak that Arthur is on the verge of losing his job. Nobody wants a stick in the mud as a colleague. Given one last shot to redeem himself, he's sent to the depressing village of Yorkshire to settle the affairs of a recently deceased woman.Upon arriving, it's pretty clear nobody wants him there, and the reason has to do with the woman's creaky old home, which as you probably suspected is plagued by an evil spirit. Aren't they all? In this case it's of a woman, wronged in life and separated forever from her dead son. As retribution, her malevolence has plagued the entire village's children, and the streets are littered with the ghosts of her victims who stare blankly out of windows and hang around the woods like creepy stalkers. The town itself is little more than a mudpit with a bit of smog surrounding it, but it's like heaven compared to the house itself, which is full of every horror cliche in the book. Creepy marionettes that look extra spooky in the dark, the type no parent would ever buy their child. Every corner is a blind hazard, every step another rickety shriek of worn out wood, and behind every door lies the possibility of a vengeful poltergeist. Shutters flap, people knock on the door at the most fearful moments. Let's just say that Arthur doesn't get a lot of work done.Radcliffe may seem like an odd choice to play a grieving widower, but he proves to be the film's greatest asset. His youthful features appear appropriately hardened by years of overwhelming grief, and you can tell his every action is labored by life's meaninglessness. But when faced with immediate danger, some of the old Harry Potter spirit comes through. In contrast to the rest of the cast, including veteran actor Ciaran Hinds, Radcliffe is the only one who seems to be bringing everything he has to what is a very understated role.It's just unfortunate that so much of the film is completely conventional. Despite director James Watkins' skillful depiction of smog and soot filled Victorian England, the script by the usually reliable Jane Goldman doesn't take us anywhere we haven't been. Atmosphere can only get you so far, and some of the film's old school horror charms wear thin from overuse. How many times are we expected to leap from our seats at a close-up of a toy monkey? Without genuine scares, the glacial pace becomes an even bigger problem. Watching both chapters of Deathly Hallows feels more brisk than this film's plodding 90 minutes.
summary: Radcliffe is the best thing about this slow moving, familiar horror

reviewText: Set in the Edwardian-era England, "The Woman in Black" is an old-fashioned horror movie that reminds us of Victorian ghost stories. This is not surprising, as the film (based on a Susan Hill novel) is produced by the newly revived Hammer studio, once known for its "Dracula" franchise starring Christopher Lee and Peter Cushing.Daniel Radcliffe is Arthur Kipps, a young lawyer on the verge of losing his position in the firm. As a final chance to keep his job, he is sent to a small British town, where he has to find a certain document at the Eel Marsh House on an estate that is cut off from the outside world. The people there obviously do not want him in their town, however. The local lawyer is not cooperative. Soon Arthur is to learn the reason - some terrifying things about "The Woman in Black."The 2012 film version of "The Woman in Black" (the original book was made into a TV movie starring Adrian Rawlins as Arthur Kipps in 1989) benefits from the atmospheric photography and the production designs of the desolate Eel Marsh House that alone is worth watching. Daniel Radcliffe turns in effective performance a widowed father, still mourning his wife's death, though he looks a little too young for the role of a father, if not a lawyer.What the film doesn't have is any new ideas to scare us. As to the film's scares, the best part is probably the "Ju-On"-inspired opening, which is creepy enough, but the film itself nds to depend on the hackneyed techniques like sudden big sound. Some of them are so predictable that you can see them coming from miles away.Perhaps we have seen so many similar-themed thrillers since the original book was published, "The Orphanage" for example, films with more inventive and creative ways to surprise and scare us. Had it been made much earlier (by ten years or more), "The Woman in Black" would have been a more scary movie.

reviewText: This flick is a good start for Daniel Radcliffes' post "Harry Potter" acting career.  Though slow moving, we are treated to a  forboding,  foggy,  English countryside atmospheric style photography throughout.  Radcliffe plays his investigator roll low key and dosen't become bigger than the picture itself.  A mothers' lament for the avoidable death of her son, takes its' toll on a small remote village, after her death.  Be prepared for a few sudden shock sequences!  This is thought provoking horror, with minimal blood and gore, akin to pictures made in the 1940's 50's and 60's.  The CGI contibution is mainly for background, rather than creating overblown fantasy creatures.  For an hour and a half Radcliffe must hold our attention.  His fans and those who enjoy ghost stories should both be satisfied.  The films ending packs an unexpected punch!

reviewText: Eureka!!!  Finally a modern day Horror film which discards CGI as an overwhelming crutch and goes for the jugular as Director James Watkins updates Writer Susan Hill's chilling ghost story 'THE WOMAN IN BLACK' and shows how true Horror films have been sorely missed over the past few decades.  The gothic Horror tale has long since been left in the dust by the supposed chillers of hacks such as Wes Craven , M. Night Shayamalan, Rob Zombie , to name but a few. With cheap tricks, gore effects,and screenplays which seem to succeed with modern audiences , none have even touched the terrifying sequences within this film.  Yes, they have their fans and supporters but they wouldn't know true Horror if it bit them where the sun don't shine.  Mr. Watkins, however, has done his homework by creating a beautifully chilling nightmare with such incredible atmosphere, you can feel the mist and fog come right through the monitor.  Daniel Radcliffe, who was criticized as being too young for the role, is excellent and Ciaran Hinds lends great support as Director Watkins glides his camera through an absolutely terrifying encounter with a haunted mansion. With a bone chilling score by Marco Beltrami and superior cinematography by Tim Maurice-Jones, this is a film that truly lives up to the cliche, 'Don't watch it alone'.  I happened to view this film with at least four other Horror fans who have seen countless ghost films over the years and I counted no fewer than 8 times that they jumped right out of their skins, something modern day Horror tries to emulate but never succeed.  The film is released by Hammer Films of England who were responsible for a literal Horror renaissance beginning in the mid fifties and lasting to the early seventies but not even those photoplays have the class of this true Horror masterpiece.  If you love the films of Val Lewton and think that the champion of all ghost stories, Director Robert Wise's 'THE HAUNTING'- 1963 is the definitive haunted house thriller , you will be surprised. If ever a film was perfect for the Blu-Ray format, this is it as Sony releases it in a beautiful 2.35 transfer with jaw dropping 5.1 DTS sound.  Ignore the negative reviews that many gave to this film and experience a truly terrifying tone poem, one that the 'PARANORMAL ACTIVITY' films try to succeed at but ultimately fail.
